instructions.text: Saut√© the onion and garlic along with a pinch of salt in a little olive oil, until the onion has softened.
Add the red peppers and sweet potato to the pan with the onion and garlic.
Add enough vegetable stock to cover all the ingredients, and simmer until the potatoes have softened.
At this point, use a hand blender, or add to a food processor, and blend into a smooth soup.

recipes.title: Garlicky white beans with kale and parmesan

instructions.text: Add the chopped garlic to a pan with a little olive oil and a good pinch of sea salt.
Allow the garlic to brown, giving a deep smokey flavour.
At this stage, add in the beans and the kale, and saute for several minutes, until the kale wilts.
Stir in 1 tablespoon of parmesan and mix through thoroughly and allow to melt. When the dish is served, sprinkle the remaining parmesan over the top.

ingredients.text: handfuls of shredded green vegetables (spring greens, cabbage, kale etc)
½ a red onion, finely sliced

instructions.text: Add the onion, garlic, and chilli to a pan or a wok, with a little olive oil, and saute until the onion has started to soften.
Add in the greens, and saute until they have softened slightly and turned a brighter colour.
At this stage, add the soy sauce and honey, and stir the peanut butter through everything, until well mixed.
Sprinkle over the 5 spice powder, and mix thoroughly.

ingredients.text: 2 large, ripe avocados, stoned, peeled and diced (1cm / ¬Ω inch cubes)
1 large red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
Salt and freshly ground black pepper

instructions.text: Place the diced avocado in a bowl and squeeze over the lime juice.
Add the remaining ingredients to the bowl and season with a little salt and lots of freshly ground black pepper.
To serve as a starter, fill four teacups with the relish and turn out onto the centre of each serving plate. Drizzle over olive oil and finish with black pepper and serve with bread.

ingredients.text: 225 g boneless, skinless chicken thighs, roughly cut into pieces
15 g jalapeno chillies in a jar, drained and rinsed
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
4 granary maps and salad leaves, to serve

instructions.text: In a small pan, heat the oil. Add the onion and fry for 5 minutes until softened. Add the garlic and ground coriander and cook for a further minute.
Transfer to a food processor and add the remaining ingredients. Whizz together and season. Using wet hands form the mix into 4 burgers and chill for 30 minutes.
To cook, brush a griddle pan with a little oil and gently fry the burgers for 6-7 minutes each side until cooked.

ingredients.text: 1½ oz of your favorite Irish whisky

instructions.text: Whip the heavy cream until it becomes whipped cream. Add sugar to sweeten and place in the fridge to chill.
Brew the fresh coffee and combine it with the whisky and sugar. Mix well until the sugar dissolves
Take the whipped cream out of the fridge and place it on top of the Irish coffee mixture.

ingredients.text: 2 hard boiled eggs, cut into quarters
50 ml noilly prat or dry white wine

instructions.text: Stud the onion with the clove and bay leaf and put into the milk and fish stock. Add the haddock and coley and bring to a simmer then leave to stand for 5 minutes.
Melt the butter in a saucepan, add the flour and make a roux. Cook this out for 2 minutes, drain the fish and reserve the liquid to use to make the white sauce.
Take the roux, add the alcohol and the cooking liquid a little at a time and stir constantly. Add the Dijon mustard and cream and cook out.
Whilst the sauce is cooking saut√© the spinach for thirty seconds in a teaspoon of butter, season and drain on a kitchen towel.

Pass the sauce through a sieve, add the chopped chives and season to taste. Flake the haddock and coley into a gratin dish with the quartered egg slices, saut√©d spinach and prawns then pour over the warm sauce so it just covers the ingredients.

Lay over the thinly-sliced plum tomato then spoon or pipe over the warm mashed potato. Brush with beaten egg yolk then scatter over some parmesan cheese and pop under a hot grill for 5 minutes until brown and bubbling.
Serve with peas.

ingredients.text: 1 vanilla pod, split and seeds removed
Pinch of cornflour or custard powder

instructions.text: Place the milk and vanilla pod together in a pan and bring to the boil.
Meanwhile, whisk the egg yolks, cornflour and caster sugar together until thick and pale.
Pour on the boiling milk, whisk well and return to the pan and cook over a very low heat until thickened and coating the back of the spatula.
Immediately remove from the pan and strain, pushing through all the seeds from the pod.
Serve warm with puddings, cool with poached fruits and flans or warm with pies and crumbles.

ingredients.text: Salt and freshly ground black pepper, to season

instructions.text: Make up the suet crust by combining the flour and suet with enough water to make a dough. Season with salt and freshly ground black pepper then roll out to form an oblong.
Cover this with the bacon, herbs, the finely chopped onion and one tomato.
Next, roll it up into a Swiss roll shape, carefully tucking in the ends.
Wrap loosely (to allow expansion) in greased tinfoil or greaseproof paper and tinfoil.
Steam for about 2 hours (although you can leave it steaming until you are ready).

recipes.title: Crab spring rolls with fresh mango chutney

ingredients.text: 1 egg yolk for the egg wash
A pinch of grated fresh ginger
A dash of tabasco and Worcestershire sauce
A sprinkle of corn flour for dusting
1 mango, peeled and diced (little finger nail-sized pieces)
100 g glass noodles (bean thread noodles) cooked and chilled, sesame oil tossed through

instructions.text: Mix together all the ingredients except the filo, flour and egg. Season to taste.

Lay out 1 filo sheet, egg wash it, then lay a second one on top. Place the crab mixture at one end, fold over the edges then roll up into a spring roll shape and dust with cornflower to aid crispness.
Shallow fry in sunflower oil until golden brown.
Bring all the above ingredients apart from the mango to the boil, once boiled pour over the mango, cover with plastic wrap and allow to infuse for 2-3 hours.
Toss the noodles with a little of the mango liquor, then add the mint and coriander leaves.
Place the spring roll on top of the chutney and then top with the salad.

recipes.title: Pan-fried gurnard fillets with purple sprouting broccoli

ingredients.text: 220 g red gurnard fillet, pin bones removed
1 small blood orange segmented and juice reserved
8 small jersey royals, scrubbed and par boiled
Olive oil,Blanche the broccoli in boiling salted water until just cooked. Refresh in cold water, drain well and reserve in a bowl. for cooking
20 ml quality extra virgin olive oil

instructions.text: Blanche the broccoli in boiling salted water until just cooked. Refresh in cold water, drain well and reserve in a bowl.
Set a non-stick saut√© pan over a medium heat and add a good lug of olive oil. Season the fish fillets well.
Cut the potatoes in half and place cut side down in the pan along with the pancetta. Continue to cook until the fat leeches from the pancetta and the potatoes become caramelised.
Place in the fish fillets skin side down and cook for 2-3 minutes until the skin colours.
Move the potatoes and pancetta to further colour and then transfer these into the bowl with the broccoli, leaving the fish to continue to cook.

Turn over the fish and finish the cooking process then remove from the pan. Pour the orange juice into the pan and deglaze. Pour the juices into the broccoli then add the segments, extra virgin olive oil and a dash of vinegar. Season well and mix.
Divide the broccoli salad between serving plates and then top with the roasted gurnard. Serve straight away!
Peel the potatoes and wash. Cut into large even sized pieces.
Cover with cold water and bring to the boil. Simmer until cooked.
Strain off the water then put the potatoes back into the pan and heat to get rid of excess moisture.
Pass through a potato ricer or sieve into a clean bowl. Beat in the chopped butter and the heated double cream to the consistency you like.
Season and serve.

Brian's top tips: Choose a floury type potato i.e. Paris Piper or King Edwards. Make sure the potatoes are cooked through and dry them well. Use a ricer or sieve to ensure no lumps and add plenty of butter to ensure smoothness and great taste.

recipes.title: Pork with Kentish cider and apple sauce

ingredients.text: 1 jar of Countrywise Kentish Cider and Apple sauce

instructions.text: Grill or griddle the pork chops until cooked.
Meanwhile, heat the sauce gently and pour over the cooked chops.

ingredients.text: Salt and freshly ground black pepper
A bunch of watercress, to serve
2 potatoes, baked and scooped from the flesh

instructions.text: Put the vinegar, chopped shallot and tarragon in a saucepan and bring to the boil. Continue to cook until reduced by about three quarters. Allow to cool and pour into a large stainless steel bowl.
Place the bowl over a pan of just-simmering water, add the egg yolks and whisk until you can see the whisk leaving a pattern in the sauce (this is called the ribbon stage).

Remove the bowl from the heat and put it on a folded cloth (to keep the heat in) on a work surface, then start to add the melted butter, little by little, whisking all the time until all the butter is used or your arm has fallen off!
Preheat a griddle pan over a high flame, or heat a little butter in a heavy frying pan, and preheat the oven to 200C/Gas 6.
Season the steaks and rub well with olive oil.

If using a griddle pan, cook for 3 minutes on a very high heat, turn and cook for a further 3 minutes on the other side, to produce medium-rare steaks. Increase or decrease these times by a minute if you prefer your steaks well done or rare.
Alternatively, seal the steak quickly on both sides and transfer to the oven for about 5-10 minutes, depending on how rare you like your meat.
Allow the steaks to rest briefly in a warm place, and then serve with a little watercress and b√©arnaise sauce on the side.

Bake the potatoes in a preheated oven (180C/Gas 4) until done. Scoop out the inside from the flesh and mash with a knob of butter (or to taste). Add in the tarragon, salt and pepper. Make large quenelles of the potato mixture and place alongside the steak and watercress leaves.

recipes.title: Beef steak pie with stout and mushroom sauce

ingredients.text: 1 pack of ready to use puff pastry
1 jar of Countrywise Stout and Mushroom sauce
1 egg, beaten, or milk, for glazing the pastry

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4.
Heat the oil in a pan, add the beef and fry until the meat is browned (approximately 5 minutes).
Add the jar of sauce to the pan and stir until hot.
Transfer to an oven-proof dish and cover with a layer of puff pastry.
Lightly brush with the beaten egg or milk.
Place in the oven and cook until golden brown for 35-40 minutes.

recipes.title: Chocolate and morello cherry fridge cake

ingredients.text: 200 g good quality dark chocolate (about 70% cocoa solids)
90 g amaretti or digestives (also ginger nuts will do)
25 g shelled pistachio nuts, coarsely chopped
50 g Morello cherries from a jar, drained of syrup, halved
2 heaped tbsp live thick Greek-style yoghurt
1 vanilla pod, split, seeds scraped out
2 tbsp light muscovado sugar, or to taste

instructions.text: Line a 900g loaf tin with foil or greaseproof paper.

Melt the chocolate, golden syrup and butter together gently in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of barely simmering water. Stir to combine and take off the heat. Let cool slightly, then stir in the beaten egg.

Break the amaretti into large chunks, place in a bowl and sprinkle over the kirsch. Add in the chopped almonds, walnuts, pistachios and cherries. Pour the warm chocolate mixture over, stir gently until evenly mixed and the into the loaf tin. Place in the fridge for 4 hours to set (or longer if you want to make it in advance). A quick cheat is to place it in the freezer for 30 minutes.

When ready to serve, remove from the fridge (or freezer) and turn it out onto a board. Peel off the foil or paper and cut the cake into thin slices, using a sharp knife. It's lovely served with cream (method follows) or creme fraiche and red berries on the side.
Place a muslin-lined large sieve over a bowl and scrape the mascarpone, fromage frais and yoghurt into it. Leave to drain for an hour, or longer (up to two hours) if it suits you.

To finish the cream, pull up all four corners of the muslin and squeeze out the remaining liquid. Pour the liquid away, and then turn the contents of the muslin out into the sieve. Push this through into the empty bowl with a wooden spoon. Fold in the vanilla seeds, lemon zest and sugar, to taste.
Whisk the egg white in a separate bowl to firm peaks and lightly fold into the cream.
Serve with the chocolate and cherry fridge cake.

Add a little oil to a hot pan and fry the onion, carrot and celery for 5-6 minutes until softened. Add the garlic, rosemary and oregano and continue to cook for a couple more minutes, then add the wine and reduce by half.

Flour the lamb, then in a dash of oil in a separate pan, fry it off in batches until browned. Set aside. Deglaze the pan with stock and scrape up any residue from the pan. Add this to the vegetables along with the tomatoes and the lamb pieces and simmer gently for 20 minutes.

In a preheated griddle pan, cook the oiled aubergine slices for 1-2 minutes per side then set aside. Layer the lamb and aubergines to an oven-proof dish then lay on a sheet of filo. Brush with butter then layer on another sheet then repeat the process a few more times, scrunching up the edges as you go. Brush with a final coating of butter, then cook in a preheated oven set at 190C/170C fan/Gas 5 for 30-35 minutes.
Serve with the spinach leaf and feta salad.

Toast the pine nuts in a dry pan until golden then set aside. Dress the spinach and onion with the lemon juice and olive oil, then crumble over the feta. Sprinkle on the pine nuts and serve with the lamb.

ingredients.text: Knob of butter or vegetable oil, for cooking
3 large cooking apples, peeled, cored and diced
1 vanilla pod, split lengthways and seeds removed
Maple syrup and clotted cream, to serve

instructions.text: Sift the flour and salt into a large bowl and make a well in the centre, crack the eggs and add 3/4 of the milk whisk everything together then add remaining milk, whisk until a smooth thin batter.

Heat small amount of oil or butter in non stick pan then pour off any excess hot fat. Coat the base of the pan with a thin layer of batter and cook for around 40 seconds, flip or turn with a palette knife and cook on the other side. Slide onto a plate and repeat the process and stack up pancakes between sheets of non stick baking paper until required.

For the compote, put the apples, vanilla pod, butter, sugar, cinnamon and a splash of water in a saucepan. Cook, stirring often, until the apples turn into a chunky puree. Mix in the sultanas and heat through then remove the vanilla pod. Keep the puree warm and set aside.
Serve the pancakes stacked up with the compote and garnish with clotted cream and a drizzle of maple syrup.

Simply heat the cream in a saucepan on the hob to just simmering, lower the heat and whisk in the chocolate until melted, scoop the ice cream onto the pancakes drizzle over sauce and sprinkle over marshmallows.

ingredients.text: 2 thick slices of crusty country bread

instructions.text: Melt some butter into a hot pan before adding the shallot.
Add a sprinkle of thyme leaves and a spoonful of flour to the mixture and gently stir to form a roux.
Pour in a splash of dark beer to the pan mixing well until the roux becomes liquid. Add the cheese and melt and mix thoroughly.
Toast the bread. Add a few drops of Worcestershire sauce, then spoon the mixture onto your toasted bread.
Place in a very hot oven, or under the grill, and cook until the cheese has browned and bubbled slightly and goes golden.
Serve with a glass of the remaining beer.
Place the couscous in a large bowl, pour in the vegetable stock and add the sultanas.
After 5 minutes, fluff up the grains with a fork.
Stir in the tomatoes, cucumber, grapes and parsley.
Combine the meatball ingredients in a bowl and shape into 12 walnut-sized balls.
Preheat the grill to medium-high heat and grill the meatballs for 15 minutes, turning occasionally.
Combine the yoghurt, mint and lemon juice in a bowl.
Serve the couscous with the meatballs with a spoon of the yoghurt mixture on top.

ingredients.text: 1 red pepper, deseeded and roughly chopped
3 large potatoes, peeled, chopped and boiled
350 g just cooked salmon, roughly flaked

instructions.text: Heat 4 tbsp of oil and soften the onions, garlic and peppers for 10 minutes.
Mash the cooked warm potatoes.
Add the salmon to the warm potatoes, breadcrumbs, egg white then add the onions and peppers and mix well, but lightly.
Season well with salt and pepper and add a little more oil to moisten slightly.
Chill well then, when cold, form into a single cake, or two smaller ones.
Heat a little vegetable oil in a non stick, oven proof frying pan.
Add the fish cake mix, press down and cook for about 4-5 minutes on each side.
Make the herb mayo by whizzing all the ingredients together in a food processor.
Serve hot topped with a poached egg and herb mayonnaise.

ingredients.text: 4 rashers of smoked bacon, rind removed

instructions.text: Place minced rabbit and minced chicken into a mixing bowl.
Finely dice the smoked bacon and add it to the rabbit/chicken mixture.
Add the chopped parsley, a spoonful of wholegrain mustard and a pinch of salt to the mixture, as well as plenty of black pepper.
Soak the de-stoned prunes in whisky. Chop the prunes and add to the meat mixture along with a handful of breadcrumbs.
Mix the meat thoroughly and form the mixture into burger sized patties.
Melt some butter in a large pan and brown the individual faggots on both sides until partially cooked.
Remove the faggots and in the same pan add sliced onion, chopped garlic, beef stock and cider. Allow to bubble, before adding the partly cooked faggots to the liquor.
Simmer the faggots in the liquor for 10 minutes. Remove and quickly reduce the sauce until it thickens.
Serve with a green salad and crusty bread.

ingredients.text: 3 chillies, as hot or as mild as you like
Fresh ratatouille, homemade or purchased pre-made

instructions.text: With a sharp knife or heavy duty pair of scissors, chop down either side of the back bone of the partridges and remove from the carcass.
For the marinade, mix the lemon juice, chopped garlic, chilli, rosemary and oregano together.
Add a spoonful of tomato puree, a pinch of salt and plenty of olive oil.
Place the partridges into a freezer bag or two along with the marinade and rub into the meat. Leave in the marinade for at least 2 hours.
To cook, open the partridges out, and place skin side down onto a preheated griddle pan or barbecue. Allow to cook for 20-30 minutes, turning regularly, over a medium heat, do no cook too hot.
Serve with salad, crusty bread and fresh ratatouille.

ingredients.text: Enough caster sugar to coat the bottom of a pan to 5mm (depends on the size of your pan)
Enough apples to fill the pan, peeled, halved and cored
Puff pastry, enough to cover the pan
Creme fraiche or vanilla ice cream, to serve

instructions.text: Place the sugar into a warm non-stick oven-proof pan and stir with a wooden spoon. Melt the sugar over a medium heat, until it gradually turns to a golden caramel. Allow the caramel to colour until just before the burning point, (have the courage to go almost burnt, but not beyond) you watch a deep caramel colour.
Take off the heat and add two knobs of butter and allow the mixture to froth.
Place the apples, cored side up, into the caramel. Place back on a medium heat and cook for 5 minutes. Remove from the heat and lay over the puff pastry. Poke 2-3 holes in the top.
Put the pan straight into the oven for 20 minutes at 200C/Gas 6 or until the pastry has turned golden and is cooked.
When done, place a large wooden board over the pan and turn out. Be careful not to burn yourself on the hot caramel.
Finish with shaved almonds on the top and serve with creme fraiche or vanilla ice cream.
Brush the pork with butter, sprinkle with pepper and lay 5-6 sage leaves on top.
Lay out the prosciutto and place the pork loin on top. Wrap the loin with the prosciutto.
Place onto a griddle pan and brush with butter. Cook in the oven for 10-12 minutes at 200C/Gas 6.

In a separate pan, fry the garlic in the olive oil, and add the halved tomatoes, the sliced chorizo, diced shallot and remaining sage leaves. Add a splash of white wine and cook for 5 minutes until soft.
Add the flageolet beans to the mixture and leave to simmer for 5-10 minutes.
Take the pork out of the oven and leave to rest for 5 minutes on a wooden board.
Add some finely chopped basil leaves to the cassoulet and season to taste.
Place the bean mixture onto a plate, top with the sliced pork and serve.

recipes.title: Wild mushroom and puy lentil forest stew

instructions.text: Add the butter to a heavy bottomed casserole dish, melt and add finely chopped shallots and 3 cloves of finely chopped garlic. Sweat in the butter then add the puy lentils. Add a glass of white wine and a glass of water and cook very gently. Add the celery and carrot and cook gently with a lid on, adding water as necessary. This will take about 30 minutes to cook.
In another pan, dry cook the sweet chestnuts in their shells for a few minutes. Remove the flesh from the chestnuts and set aside.
Add the butter to the hot pan and fry the mixed wild mushrooms.
Add the three remaining finely chopped garlic cloves to the mushrooms.
Add some chopped chunks of chorizo into the pan and stir.
While the mushroom mix is cooking add some roughly torn black cabbage leaves to the lentils.
Add the sweet chestnuts and finally a sprinkling of chanterelle mushrooms to the wild mushroom mixture.
Place a generous amount of lentils onto a plate, and top with the mushroom mixture.
Coat the brisket in mustard powder and salt, fry in olive oil until it's dark all over.
Melt the butter in a separate casserole dish and fry the onions until dark and golden. Season, add bay leaves, ketchup, beer and beef stock.
Place the brisket in the onion stock, cover with greaseproof paper, put the lid on and cook at 150C for 4 hours.
Remove the brisket from the liquid and leave to rest covered in foil. Reduce the liquid by half.
At the final moment, add the oysters to the liquid and allow to cook through. Slice the brisket and serve with mashed potato and cover with juices and the oysters.

ingredients.text: 550 g potatoes, peeled and cut into chunks
1 slice of wholegrain bread blended into breadcrumbs

instructions.text: In a non-stick pan dry-fry the lean minced beef with onion and carrots until the mince is browned. Stir in flour, tomato pur√©e, thyme and seasoning.
Add stock, bring to the boil and cook for 5-10 minutes until the carrots are just soft.
Meanwhile, in a large pan, bring potatoes to the boil and cook for 20 minutes or until soft. Once cooked, drain and mash with spread, milk and season with pepper.
Transfer the mince into an ovenproof dish and spoon mash over the top. Sprinkle with cheese and breadcrumbs.
Cook in a pre-heated oven for 25-30 minutes until golden brown.

recipes.title: Butternut squash, feta and caramelised red onion filo rolls

instructions.text: Start by placing the cubed squash into a roasting tin, drizzle with olive oil, and roast in a hot oven (gas 9/200) for around 30 minutes, until soft enough to mash.
Saute the onion and garlic in a little olive oil until the on onion has softened. Stir in the honey and continue to saut√© until the onions have become sticky and caramelised.
Place the roasted squash into a bowl, and mash with a fork. Stir in the onion mixture and mix well.

Cut the film pastry into sheets about the size of a piece of A5 paper. Layer three sheets thick. Spread a thin layer f the squash mixture along one edge of the sheet. Crumble a generous helping of feta on top of the squash mix. Then roll the film pastry up, tucking in the edges as you go.
Bake in a medium oven for around 15 minutes, until the pastry is golden brown.
Preheat oven to 220C.
Line a deep-sided roasting tray with foil and place over metal rack/trivet.

Slice the pork skin with a sharp knife through to the fat at 2cm spaces all along the belly. Season the meat side with a little salt and pepper and squeeze lemon juice onto the skin. Sprinkle on the salt and place the belly on to grease-proof paper. Tuck the sage sprigs evenly under the belly.
Put the pork into the oven and cook at full heat for 45 minutes. Then turn the oven down to 160C and cook for a further 3 hours
Peel and chop the apples and add to a pan with all the other ingredients.
Bring the mixture to the boil, turn down the heat and cook slowly for 20 minutes. Mash till almost smooth.
Serve the pork and apple sauce with with mustard seed mash, buttered carrots and gravy.

ingredients.text: 300 g white flour, type ‚Äú00‚Äù, plus extra for dusting

instructions.text: Sift the flour into a large bowl. Make a well in the centre and break in the eggs. Add in the salt and oil.

Using the handle of a wooden spoon, mix the edge of the pile into the eggs. Once you have a crumble texture, tip the mixture onto a well floured surface and start to knead until you have a soft dough. Once the dough has come together, continue to knead for about 8 minutes using both hands as if you are kneading bread.
Roll the dough into a ball, cover with clean film and leave to rest in the fridge for 20 minutes.
Dust the work surface, the dough and the rolling pin with the flour to prevent sticking.

Start by flattening the dough with the palm of your hand, then place the rolling pin across the dough and roll it towards the centre. Continue to roll the pin backwards and forwards turning the dough every so often. At this point the dough should spread out and flatten evenly. When it is thin enough that you can see your fingers trough it, it‚Äôs ready.
Start to roll the pasta sheet like a flattened cigar from one edge to the centre, and then repeat from the other edge to the centre.

Make sure that it is well floured, then with a sharp long knife, cut into 5mm wide strips. Slide the knife beneath the rolled pasta sheet, lining up the edge of the knife with the centre of the folds. Gently lift the knife up and the pasta ribbons will fall down on each side.
Toss the tagliatelle with a little more flour and cook within the hour.

ingredients.text: 1 large tin of cannellini beans, drained & rinsed

instructions.text: Heat the oil in a large saucepan over a medium heat. Add the chopped onion and garlic and gently fry, without browning, for 2-3 minutes. Add the carrots, celery and courgettes and cook for a further 4-5 minutes.
Stir in the tomatoes. Fill the tomato can with water twice and mix into the vegetables along with the chopped basil. Season with black pepper and allow the soup to simmer gently for 30 minutes.
Add the drained cannellini beans and the chopped cabbage, and simmer gently for a further 30 minutes.
Sprinkle with grated Parmesan before serving.
Place the flour, eggs and half the milk into a large bowl.
Whisk slowly, gradually incorporating the flour from the edge of the bowl.
Finally add the rest of the milk and whisk well, then add salt and pepper, then leave for 30 minutes to 1 hour.
Preheat the oven to 220C/ gas mark 7.
Place the lard into a 25cm non-stick frying pan. Add the sausages and brown nicely. Pour into the hot sausage pan and quickly place into the hot oven.
Straight away reduce the temperature to 200C/ gas mark 6.
Cook for 25-35 minutes or until well risen and golden around the edges.
When you think they are cooked, leave for a further 10 minutes.
Once cooked, remove from the oven and eat straight away with onion gravy.
Cook the pasta quills in boiling salted water for 8-10 minutes until just tender.

Meanwhile, melt the butter in a large pan, add the garlic, and cook, stirring for 1 minute. Add the mushrooms and cook stirring occasionally, for 2 minutes. Stir in the cream and boil for 2-3 minutes until the mixture reaches a coating consistency.

Drain the pasta, add to the mushroom and cream mixture with the egg (if using), stir well, and heat through. Add the spinach, stilton, lemon juice, nutmeg and pepper to taste, and stir well to coat the pasta. Serve at once.

ingredients.text: 4 large potatoes of similar sizes, washed and peeled
4 tbsp vegetable oil plus enough oil for frying the potatoes
2 large onions peeled and thinly sliced
Salt and freshly ground pepper to season

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C/350F.
Cut the potatoes in half lengthwise. Hollow out the potatoes with a melon baller creating a shell approximately ¬Ω inch thick. Discard the potato pulp.
Heat enough oil in a skillet until hot and brown the potatoes. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on kitchen paper.
In a separate pan heat the 4 tablespoons of oil until hot and add the onions. Saute until the onions are soft, then add the garlic and continue to cook for a minute.

Add the minced beef and cook until the meat is browned all over. Stir in the tomato puree along with the cinnamon and allspice. Mix thoroughly and continue to cook for several minutes. Add add the coriander, mint, parsley, eggs, salt and pepper and mix thoroughly. Remove the pan from the heat and allow the mixture to cool slightly.
Fill the potatoes with the stuffing, then arrange the potatoes in an ovenproof dish.
Mix together the tomato juice, beef stock, cinnamon, allspice, sugar, salt and pepper.
Pour the mixture around the potatoes, cover and bake in the oven for approximately an hour, basting occasionally with the juices. Cook until tender and adjust seasoning.
Serve with flat bread, fresh herbs, Persian pickles and yoghurt with roasted garlic.

ingredients.text: 4 boneless lamb leg steaks, fat removed

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 200C, Gas Mark 6.
Pour 1 tbsp of the olive oil into a roasting pan, then add the chopped rosemary and new potatoes. Toss in the oil to coat, then roast in the oven for 30‚Äì35 minutes, until cooked through and golden.
Meanwhile, heat the remaining oil in a pan and brown the lamb steaks on each side. Remove with a slotted spoon and set aside.

Saut√© the onion in the same pan for 2 minutes before adding the leek and carrots. Cook for 2‚Äì3 minutes, then return the lamb to the pan, cover and cook over a low heat for about 20 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent it sticking.
Add the green beans to the pan, cover and cook for another 5 minutes.
Serve the lamb on top of the vegetables with the rosemary-roasted potatoes.

recipes.title: Tuscan bean stew with parmesan croutons

ingredients.text: 2 medium sized red onions chopped finely
Good handful of picked Cavolo nero cabbage
150 g dried borlotti beans (you can use a can of ready cooked beans)
150 g dried cannellini beans (you can use a can of ready cooked beans)
4 ripe plum tomatoes, chopped (or a good can of chopped/plum tomatoes)
½ fresh French stick, cut 1cm thick pieces at an angle for the croutons, toasted on one side

instructions.text: Rinse the dried beans under cold water for 10 minutes, (preferably soak over night in water) place into a pan, cover with water and bring to the boil. Turn the heat down and cook for a further 10 minutes, turn off the heat and allow to cool.

Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a pan, add the chopped onions, carrots and celery and cook for 2 minutes. Add the garlic, chilli, thyme and bayleaf season and cook for a further few minutes until they have a very slight colour and the aromas from the herbs start to release.
Add the beans, fresh tomatoes and tomato puree, stir then add the stock, bring to the boil, turn the heat down and cook for 40 minutes on a low heat stirring occasionally.
After 40 minutes add the cavalo nero and the dried pasta and cook for a further 10-12 minutes, until the pasta and beans are tender and cooked through
Mix the above ingredients, spread on top of the un toasted side of the croutons, then place under the gill until golden brown, serve alongside the stew
Drizzle with olive oil and serve with the parmesan croutons.
Simply whizz all ingredients together in a juicer.

ingredients.text: 100 g good quality plain dark chocolate, finely chopped
Low fat cr√®me fraiche, to serve

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4.
Grease a 23cm (9in) loose-bottomed cake tin with a little low-fat spread and line the base with baking parchment.
Sift the cocoa, flour and baking powder into a large mixing bowl. Add the sugar and mix with a wooden spoon to combine.
Drain the beetroot, reserving the juice, then put the beetroot in a food processor along with the eggs and the olive oil and blitz until smooth.
Now, make a well in the centre of the dry ingredients and, using a wooden spoon, beat in the beetroot mixture, a bit at a time to form a smooth batter.

Next, add the chopped chocolate and combine well. Pour the mixture into the prepared cake tin and bake for 40‚Äì45 minutes or until a skewer inserted into the centre of the cake comes out clean. Allow to cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack and cool.

To make the icing, simply mix the icing sugar with a little of the reserved beetroot juice to make a deep purple pourable icing. Drizzle the icing over the cake and serve with a dollop of low-fat cr√®me fra√Æche.

ingredients.text: 4 large free range eggs, whites and yolks separated
3 oranges, cut into segments (use the ones you zested for the sponge)
4 tbsp half fat cr√®me fraiche, to serve

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4.
First make the sponge, whisk the egg yolks and sugar until pale and creamy. Next, whisk the egg whites until stiff then fold into the yolks.
Fold in the flour, cocoa powder and orange zest. Pour into a greased and lined baking tin (a 20cm square sponge tin is ideal). Bake for 20 minutes or until golden and cooked through.

Meanwhile, make the orange syrup. Mix the tablespoon of caster sugar, with the split vanilla pod, any juice from the orange segments and the mint stalks and cover with water. Bring to a simmer and cook for 1 minute, cool slightly then drain with a sieve over the orange segments and mint leaves. Leave to cool fully.

Remove from the sponge from the oven and dust with a little more cocoa powder (this is optional). Slice sponge into wedges and serve with a dollop of cr√®me fraiche, the orange segments, mint and a drizzle of the vanilla syrup. Garnish with extra fresh mint sprigs.

ingredients.text: Sea salt and freshly ground black pepper
20 g salted capers, rinsed and well drained
A pinch of dried chilli flakes

instructions.text: Drain the olives and pat dry. With a sharp knife, make 3 or 4 cuts in each olive from end to end, then cut each segment away from the stone as carefully as you can.
Heat some extra virgin olive oil in a pan, then put in the swordfish, season and seal on all sides. Lift out and set aside.
Add the spring onions, garlic, capers, olives, chilli and anchovy fillets to the pan, and cook gently until the anchovies 'melt' into the oil and the onion is translucent.
Add the white wine and bubble up to evaporate the alcohol, then add the tomatoes and passata.
Mix well, cover and leave to cook for 30 minutes on a very low heat, adding the swordfish for the last 10-12 minutes. Serve sprinkled with the parsley and garlic.

ingredients.text: 2 thick slices of day old bread
750 g ripe tomatoes, peeled and de-seeded

instructions.text: Place the crushed garlic cloves in a bowl with the vinegar and sugar.
Next, tear the bread into small pieces, blend into breadcrumbs and add to the vinegar mixture. Leave to soak for 10 minutes.
Meanwhile, dice the pepper and onion, roughly chop the tomatoes and place in the blender with the cucumber. Add the bread mix and pour over the 2 tablespoons of olive oil.
Blend until smooth, then blend for a further 30 seconds.

Toast the desiccated coconut in a dry pan until just coloured and set aside to cool. Blend the coconut to a powder in a mini blender. (This is optional but will add to the texture). Meanwhile par boil the potatoes for 10 minutes, then drain and set aside along with the coconut.

Fry the onion in some oil over a medium heat for 10 minutes until browned. Very finely chop the garlic, ginger, and chilli then add to the onions along with the bruised lemongrass and cook for 5 minutes. Add the garam masala, turmeric, paprika and cinnamon and then the potatoes, cauliflower florets and sugar. Pour in the coconut milk and water then bring to the boil, reduce to a medium heat and cook uncovered for around 15-25 minutes or until tender. Keep an eye on the curry and if it starts to stick or become too dry then just add a splash of water but remember it is supposed to be a dry curry.

The sauce should be thick, rich and coating the veg, if not turn up the heat and reduce the sauce for a few minutes. Stir in the desiccated coconut, season with salt, pepper and a squeeze of lime juice. Remove the lemongrass stalks before serving.
Sprinkle over the coriander, and serve with rice.

ingredients.text: 200 g smoked haddock fillet, skin removed

instructions.text: Melt the butter in a deep pan and add the olive oil, garlic, onions and potatoes.
Sprinkle in a pinch of salt and cook gently until the onions have softened. Pour in the fish stock and simmer for a further 10 minutes.
Cut the haddock into chunks and add to the pan.
Cook on a gentle heat for 5 minutes or until the potato is cooked through.
To give the soup a chunky texture, remove a quarter of the lumps in the soup and place to one side. Blend the remainder of the soup until smooth.
Pour in the double cream and stir.
Return the soup to the pan along with the reserved chunks and heat gently before serving.

ingredients.text: 1 blade of mace or 1/2 tsp ground mace
A good pinch of cayenne pepper

instructions.text: Mix the lemon zest with the shrimps.
Gently fry the shallots in a little of the butter until soft. Allow to cool and mix with the shrimps.
In a pestle and mortar grind the mace to a powder, add this along with the cayenne to the shrimps. Season with a little salt and pepper.
Melt the butter in a pan over a gentle heat. Using a metal spoon, skim off the white froth from the top of the butter so that you are left with a clear yellow liquid.
Spoon the shrimps into individual ramekin dishes and press down firmly. Pour over the butter. Make sure the shrimps are completely covered with an even layer of butter on top.
Cover with cling film and leave to set in the fridge.
Serve with slices of bread, lettuce leaves and pink grapefruit segments and a drizzle of balsamic vinegar.
Gently fry the onions and garlic in olive oil until soft. Take off the heat and put into a large mixing bowl.
Add in the minced beef and the egg. Mix well.
Sprinkle over the flour, nutmeg and season well.
Make sure everything is combined well then roll into 8 balls, then flatten into burgers with your hands.
Grill or fry the burgers until they're cooked.
Cut the figs in half, scoop out the flesh and discard the skins.
Heat the olive oil in a pan and gently fry the diced shallots. Add the pecans and cook for a further 3-4 minutes.
Pour in the red wine vinegar and stir in the sugar.
Leave to simmer, stirring occasionally until it begins to reduce and thicken.
Add the figs and stir everything together. Leave on a gentle heat to reduce to a thick, sticky relish.

ingredients.text: 2 large turkey thighs, de-boned and tendons removed
6 slices streaky bacon, diced into cubes
6 slices of bread, blended to crumbs

instructions.text: In a pan, gently fry the bacon, white onion, sliced peppers celery and fennel. Cool until soft then remove from the pan and set aside.
Meanwhile, in a bowl mix together the chopped prunes, breadcrumbs, thyme and chestnuts. Bind together with the beaten egg yolk.
Remove the vegetables and bacon from the pan and leave to one side.
Take the turkey thighs (all bones and tendons removed) and stuff with the breadcrumb mixture, holding the thigh together using kebab skewers or you can tie them with butcher's string.
To braise the turkey thighs, place in an oven-proof dish (with a lid) over a low heat.
Pour over the verjus and allow to cook for 60-90 minutes, turning regularly.
For the remaining 10 minutes, add the bacon and vegetables to the pan to finish cooking.
To make the batter, combine the plain flour and the bicarbonate of soda and slowly whisk in the beer.
Dry the calamari rings then coat in the batter. Deep fat fry at 180C for 2-3 minutes until the batter is golden brown.
To make the tarragon mayonnaise, set an electric whisk on a low setting and beat together the egg yolks and Dijon.
Gradually pour in the oil and continue to whisk until the mayonnaise is a smooth yellow colour. Sprinkle with tarragon and serve with the calamari.

ingredients.text: 500 g pasta, cooked as per packet instruction
25 g parmesan, grated (use vegetarian parmesan to keep this a vegetarian dish)

instructions.text: Toast the walnut in a hot dry pan, tossing so they do not burn.
Meanwhile wrap the garlic in foil, drizzle with olive oil and roast in the oven for 25 minutes at 200C/Gas 6.
Reserving a few pumpkin seeds for later, place the rest in a pestle and mortar and grind together with the chopped sage leaves.
Squeeze garlic out of its skin and add to the pestle and mortar.
Pour in 2/3 of the olive oil and grind together to make a paste. Add in the parmesan.
Gently fry the shallots with the reserved pumpkin seeds in the remaining olive oil.
Stir in the paste from the pestle and mortar, when heated add the spinach.
Once the spinach has wilted add the toasted walnuts, and finally stir in the cr√®me fraiche and allow the sauce to warm through.
To serve, stir through the cooked pasta and top with a grating of parmesan.
Gently fry the onions and diced pepper until soft. Add the pine nuts and cook for a further couple of minutes. Stir in the smoked paprika.
Remove from the heat and stir in the lemon juice.
Meanwhile, cook the couscous according to pack instructions. Then mix in the ingredients from the frying pan.
Add the spring onions, coriander, green olives, drizzle over some olive oil, season and mix well.

To prepare the peppers for stuffing, remove a thin slice from the base so that it will stand upright in a roasting tin. Carefully cut the top off to form a lid and remove the seeds and membranes from the interior.
Stuff the peppers with the couscous and place the lids back on top, drizzle with olive oil.
Stand them upright in a roasting tin and bake for 30 minutes at 180C/Gas 4.

ingredients.text: 2 muffins, cut in half and toasted

instructions.text: For the hollandaise sauce, whisk the egg yolks together with a tablespoon of cold water.
Place over a bain-marie and gently heat, whisking continuously.
Whisk in a few cubes of butter at a time, allowing the butter to melt before adding further cubes.
Whisk continuously until the sauce has thickened, remove from the heat and stir in a pinch of nutmeg and a squeeze of lemon juice.
Poach your eggs in a shallow pan adding a sprinkle of salt and the tablespoon of vinegar to the water.

Toss the spinach in a hot pan for a couple of minutes until wilted. The water that is on the spinach after you have washed it is enough moisture for the spinach to cook in. Squeeze out the excess liquid.
To assemble, spoon the wilted spinach on top of the toasted muffin, followed by the poached egg and finally pour over the hollandaise sauce.

ingredients.text: 300 g haddock fillet, skinned and cut into 5cm square chunks
200 g smoked haddock fillet, skinned and cut into 5cm square chunks
300 g sea bass, skinned and cut into 5cm square chunks
200 g salmon fillets, skinned and cut into 5cm square chunks
4 eggs, boiled and cut in half
750 g potatoes, peeled, boiled and mashed

instructions.text: Pour the hot water and milk into a pan. Stud the white onion with the cloves, place into the pan with the bay leaves and lemon slices.
Add the fish and bring to a gentle simmer. Simmer for 2 minutes, remove the fish and place in an oven proof dish. Sprinkle over the prawns.
Discard the onion, bay leaves and lemon but reserve the cooking liquid.
Gently fry the red onion in butter until softened.
Stir in the plain flour and cook for 2 minutes.
Pour in the reserved cooking liquid stirring continuously until the mixture has thickened. Stir in the white wine.
Mix in the double cream, dill and capers. Stir well until the mixture has turned into a rich creamy sauce. Season.
Lay the hard boiled eggs on top of the fish and prawns and pour over the sauce.
Stir the butter and cheese into the mashed potatoes, spoon over the fish to form the top of the pie.
Place in a preheated oven at 180C/Gas 4 for 30 minutes.
Sift the salt, bicarbonate of soda and flour into a bowl. Mix well.
Tip in the wheat flakes, wheat germ, wheat and oat bran.
Make a well in the centre and pour in half of the buttermilk. Using your hands, bring the mixture together.
Depending on the consistency, add the remaining buttermilk a little at a time until the dough has formed a ball and the bowl is clean.
Lightly dust the work surface with flour. Split the dough in half and roll into two balls.
Slightly flatten into a disc shape, score a cross into the top of the dough and bake at 200C for 20 minutes.

ingredients.text: 500 g pasta, cooked as per packet instruction

instructions.text: Fry the mushrooms in olive oil until golden brown.
Add the garlic and half of the thyme and fry gently.
Pour in the sherry, allow the alcohol to burn off then add the cubes of butter. Stir until the butter has melted. Stir in the double cream.
When warmed through, remove from the heat and add a squeeze of lime and the remaining thyme.
Add the cooked pasta to the sauce. Coat with the sauce and serve.
To make the coulis, place the blackberries in a pan, pour in the water and sugar and leave to simmer until the blackberries break down.

Add the vanilla extract and stir. Tip into a metal sieve placed over a bowl and push the blackberry pulp through the sieve using the back of a metal spoon. This will form a thick coulis. Set to one side.
Place the nuts in a plastic bag and roughly crush with a rolling pin.
Tip the nuts into a hot, dry pan and toast until golden brown.
Sprinkle over the icing sugar, toss to coat the nuts and pour in the honey. Stir quickly being careful not to allow the honey to burn. Remove from the heat and leave to cool.
Whisk the double cream and caster sugar until thickened to soft peaks. Gently fold in the yoghurt and mix in well.
Fold in half of the honey nuts and redcurrants. Don't over mix!
To serve, dollop the cream into bowls and sprinkle over the remaining nuts and fresh redcurrants and top with the blackberry coulis.

ingredients.text: 10 large crab claws, cooked and split

instructions.text: Preheat the barbecue or oven to a medium heat with the lid down.
Crack the claws in half and expose the cooked flesh - but do not cut all the way through.
Place the claws into the barbecue and reheat for 10 minutes.
At that point, smear over the seasoned butter and recook for 10 minutes to melt.
Finally, add a little fresh coriander and serve.

ingredients.text: 200 g halloumi, cut into 1cm thick slices

instructions.text: Sprinkle the paprika over the halloumi.
Add the olive oil to a hot pan then add in the garlic and halloumi.
Cook the halloumi until it is browned on both sides. Remove from the pan and set aside.
Pour the red wine into the pan and allow to come to the boil.
Add the red wine vinegar and whisk in the honey.
When the sauce is thick and syrupy, return the halloumi to the pan.
Heat the cheese through and serve.

ingredients.text: 180 g strong plain flour, plus extra for dusting
1 tbsp extra virgin olive oil, plus extra for greasing
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 mozzarella ball (125g), drained and cut into small cubes
6 slices lean cooked ham, cut into strips

instructions.text: To prepare the dough, mix the salt and yeast together in a jug with the water. Place the flour in a large bowl, make a well in the centre and add the water mixture, along with the oil. Use a wooden spoon to mix everything well to create a wet dough.

Turn out the dough onto a clean well floured surface and work it with your hands for about 5 minutes or until smooth and elastic. Place in a greased bowl and cover with a tea towel. Leave at room temperature to rise for at least 30 minutes until the dough has nearly doubled in size. Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 220C/Gas 7.
Heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in a frying pan over a medium heat and cook the mushrooms for 3 minutes until tender, stirring occasionally.

Turn out the dough onto a floured surface and divide it into two. Use your hands to push out from the centre, creating two rounds about 25cm in diameter. Place the pizza bases on two oiled baking trays.
Spread the passata on top of the dough using the back of a tablespoon. Sprinkle with the oregano and season with salt and pepper.

Divide the mozzarella, mushrooms and olives between the pizzas and drizzle with the remaining olive oil. Cook in the middle of the oven for about 20 minutes or until the edges of the pizza are golden brown. Two minutes before the end of the cooking time, scatter over the ham and the basil. Serve hot and enjoy your capricciosa!

ingredients.text: 200 g raisins or other dried fruit

instructions.text: In a large bowl, combine all the seeds, nuts and oats together.
In a separate bowl, mix together the hot water, oil and honey.
Pour the liquid into the dry ingredients and mix well.
Pour into a tin and bake at 160C/Gas2 for 10 minutes.
Remove from the oven, stir and put back for a further 10 minutes.
Allow to cool and add the raisins.

ingredients.text: 4 halibut cheeks, or 4 thick slices of turbot or cod, weighing about 150g each
300 ml clam juice, or strong fish stock

instructions.text: Heat two pans. In one add the bacon and shallots and cook for 10 minutes, then add the mushrooms and stock or juice.
Cook until you have reduced the liquid by two thirds, then turn off the heat and stir in the cold butter and parsley, keep warm.
Heat the olive oil in the second pan, whilst that is heating dust the fish with a little flour, then dip each piece in beaten egg and finally the breadcrumbs.
Cook the 4 pieces of fish for 5-6 minutes, then turn over and cook for a further 2-3 minutes.
Serve the fish and spoon over the sauce and serve.
For the marinade, grind together the garam masala, chilli flakes, coriander seeds, cumin and lime zest in a mortar and pestle.
Add the lime juice and sunflower oil and mix well.
Coat the chicken in the marinade, place in a glass dish, cover with cling film and leave to marinate in the fridge for at least an hour.
Thread the chicken pieces onto skewers. Fry them in a dry, hot pan for 5 minutes or until golden brown and cooked all the way through.

ingredients.text: 1 small bunch of coriander, finely chopped
1 small bunch of thyme, finely chopped

instructions.text: Combine the turkey, coriander, thyme, lemon zest and juice in a bowl.
Mix in the egg and breadcrumbs. Season well. Roll the mixture into balls.
For the sauce, gently fry the shallots and garlic in butter until soft in pan that is just big enough to fit the meatballs in.
Add the oregano and dill. Pour in the white wine.
Place the turkey balls into the sauce and leave to simmer on a gentle heat for 10-15 minutes or until cooked through.

recipes.title: Steamed pudding with silver birch syrup

ingredients.text: 250 ml silver birch wine, or any sweet wine

instructions.text: Pour the wine and the sugar into a pan and leave to simmer on a medium heat until it turns into a thick syrup.
Grease a 2 pint pudding bowl with butter and pour the syrup into the bottom of the bowl.
Cream together the butter and the sugar until light and fluffy.
Whisk the eggs and gradually add to the creamed butter and sugar.
Sift in the flour and fold into the mixture. Stir in the lemon zest.
Spoon in the sponge mixture to the bowl.
Place a disc of greaseproof paper over the bowl and tie around with string to secure.
Place in a steamer and leave to steam for 1 hour, checking the water level from time to time so that it doesn't boil dry.
In a pan, warm the cream and vanilla pod to just below boiling point.
In a glass bowl that will sit on a separate pan of boiling water, stir in a teaspoon of cornflour into the beaten egg. Add the sugar and mix well.
Place the bowl on the pan of simmering water on a gentle heat.
Remove the vanilla pod and gradually pour the cream into the egg and sugar, whisking continually until it turns into a thick custard.
Carefully remove the pudding from the bowl and slice into portions. Put on plates and pour the custard over. Serve.

recipes.title: Cheese, courgette and broad bean cr√™pes

instructions.text: To make the batter, sieve the flour into a bowl and make a well in the centre.
Break in the eggs and beat the mixture together. Gradually whisk in the milk and water until all the lumps are removed and the mixture is smooth.
Pour in the melted butter and whisk.
Melt a little butter in a frying pan (rub with a paper towel), place a spoonful of the batter into the centre of the pan and immediately tilt the pan from side to side, to evenly coat the bottom.

Cr√™pes are thinner than ordinary pancakes, so it will only take a few moments to turn golden brown, flip the cr√™pe over and cook for another minute. Remove from the pan, keep warm (stacked and covered with a tea towel), and repeat the process until you've used all the batter.
For the filling, gently fry the courgettes and broad beans (skinning the beans if you have time) in butter until they have softened. Add the grated cheese and allow to melt.
Place a spoonful in the middle of the cr√™pe, season to taste and roll up. Serve immediately.

recipes.title: Duo of lamb with root vegetables

ingredients.text: 6 slices of white bread, blended into breadcrumbs
½ swede, chopped into big pieces

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 160C/Gas 2.
Gently fry the onions in half of the butter until soft.
Mix half of the sage, the apricots and onions in with half of the breadcrumbs.
Season the lamb breast with salt and black pepper. Lay out flat, skin side down and spread the sage and onion stuffing on the inside. Roll the lamb breast up and secure with string.

For the topping, melt the remaining butter in a pan. Add the rest of the chopped sage and when the aroma is released, add the remaining breadcrumbs. Mix together and allow the crumbs to soak up the butter.
Sprinkle over the top of the lamb breast and slow roast in the oven for 90 minutes.
Place all the vegetables and pearl barley into a pressure cooker.
Season the lamb well with salt and black pepper and add to the pan.
Pour over boiling water until the lamb is nearly covered.
Cook in the pressure cooker on a low heat for 30 minutes.
Slice the lamb breast and serve on top of the lamb stew.

ingredients.text: 8 passion fruits, cut in half with the pulp removed (use half for the yoghurt and half to finish)

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 110C/gas 1/4.

Beat the egg whites until soft peaks form using an electric whisk then add half the caster sugar and beat until shiny. Add the remaining sugar and beat for a further 2 ‚Äì 3 minutes until you have stiff peaks.
In a separate bowl, mix together the cream of tartar, corn flour, vinegar and water and fold into the meringues gently.
Line a baking tray with greaseproof paper, then using a piping bag, pipe the mixture onto the tray in circular motions to make 4 equal sized meringues.
Place in the oven and bake for 1 hour, then turn the temperature down to 70C and cook for a further hour.
Meanwhile, sift the icing sugar into the Greek yoghurt and whisk until smooth. Stir in the pulp from 4 of the passion fruits and place into the fridge.
Remove the meringues from the oven and allow to cool.
To serve, place the meringues in the centre of the plate, spoon the yoghurt mix onto the centre then drizzle over the remaining passion fruit pulp. Sprinkle over the mint leaves and serve.

ingredients.text: 600 ml fish, chicken or vegetable stock
½ lobster, dark and light meat separated

instructions.text: Gently fry the shallots in butter and olive oil until soft. Stir in the rice, coating well.
After a couple of minutes the edges of the grains will become slightly translucent. Stir in half of the white wine.

Once the wine has been absorbed into the rice add a ladle of hot stock. Keep stirring and adding ladlefuls of hot stock, making sure each is absorbed before adding the next. This should take around 20 minutes.
At this stage, pout in the remaining wine and add the lemon zest, tarragon and darker lobster meat.
Stir until the wine is absorbed the grate in the parmesan cheese and add the remaining lobster meat, mix everything together.
Remove from the heat and stir well. Place a lid on the pan and allow to sit for 2 minutes before serving.

ingredients.text: 6 gull's eggs, or regular large eggs, beaten together
1 large handful foreshore vegetables (sea beet, purslane and samphire)

instructions.text: Melt the butter in a frying pan and gently saut√© the foreshore vegetable leaves.
Once wilted, add into the beaten eggs and stir together. Grate over a little parmesan and season.
Return the mixture to the pan and fry on a gentle heat until the egg has cooked through around the edges and is only runny in the middle.
Slide the tortilla out of the pan and onto a plate, cooked side down.
Place the pan on the tortilla and flip so the runny side is down in the pan. Return to the heat and cook for a further 3-5 minutes.
Slide onto a cutting board and cut into slices. Serve.

ingredients.text: 200 g buffalo fillet steak, seared and thinly sliced (optional)

instructions.text: Gently fry the onions and garlic until soft. Add the fresh and sun dried tomatoes and simmer on a low heat for 30-45 minutes. Blend to form a smooth sauce.
Sprinkle the yeast and sugar into the tepid water, whisk and set to one side for the yeast to activate.
Sieve the flour into a bowl, make a well in the centre and pour in the yeast mixture.
Knead the dough for 5-10 minutes and shape into a ball. Place into a greased bowl to prove for 60 minutes, until the dough has doubled in size.
Once it has doubled, gently knock the air out by re-kneading the dough. Split the mixture into four equal portions.
Lightly flour your work surface and roll the dough into a circle 5mm thick.
Spoon the sauce over so it covers the dough in an even layer. Lay the mozzarella evenly over the pizza.
Cook in the oven at 200C/Gas 6 for 10-15 minutes, or until crisp.
So the meat stays tender, cook it separately. Rub the meat in olive oil, salt and pepper and sear in a hot pan for a couple of minutes. Remove, let rest and then slice thinly.
Once the pizza is cooked, lay the buffalo slices on top, along with some torn basil leaves. Serve with a green salad.

ingredients.text: 2 large oranges, peeled and cut into segments, pith removed

instructions.text: Heat the sugar and honey until it gets to the hard-crack stage (149C). Check this using a sugar thermometer, being careful not to touch the bottom of the pan with the thermometer as that will be hotter than the sugar itself.
Remove from the heat and add the bicarbonate of soda. Stir the mixture until it starts to froth. Pour onto a greased baking tray and leave to cool.
Melt butter in a frying pan and stir in the honey.
Place the segments into the pan, and cook until they are nicely caramelised. Stir in the whiskey.
Crush the honeycomb toffee into small pieces and stir into the clotted cream with a splash of whiskey. Serve with the caramelised oranges and further crushed honeycomb.

ingredients.text: 300 g cherries, stones removed and cut in half

instructions.text: Sift the flour, cream of tartar, bicarbonate of soda, sugar and salt into a mixing bowl. Make a well in the centre and add the eggs. Whisk together into a smooth, thick mixture.
Stir in the buttermilk until it forms a smooth batter.

Rub a little butter round a frying pan (you can use a square of kitchen roll). Add spoonfuls of the batter into the pan and allow to cook on either side for a couple of minutes until golden brown. Do not crowd the pan. Add a little extra butter when you do the next batch of drop scones.
For the topping, put the cherries into a hot pan and pour over the kirsch and a sprinkle of sugar.
Turn down the heat and allow the cherries to soften and for a sticky syrup to form, stirring occasionally.
Serve the drop scones warm with hot cherries, the syrup and clotted cream.

ingredients.text: 2 punnets strawberries, stalks removed and larger ones cut in half

instructions.text: Sift the icing sugar and the flour into a bowl, add the butter.
Using your fingertips, rub the ingredients together until it is breadcrumb consistency. Mix in the lemon zest and poppy seeds.
Tip out onto a lined baking tray and press the mixture down firmly then prick all over with a fork.
Bake at 160C/Gas 2 for 20-25 minutes, or until golden brown.
As soon as it comes out of the oven, sprinkle over the caster sugar and cut into shapes.
Pour the wine into a pan, add the sage leaves, peppercorns, sugar and the lemon juice and bring to a gentle simmer.
Add the strawberries and leave to cook over a low heat for 30 minutes.
Allow to cool then remove the sage and peppercorns.
Break the chocolate into a bowl placed over a pan of gently simmering water. Allow to melt then stir and remove from the heat.
Dip the almonds in the chocolate and leave to set on greaseproof paper.

Spoon the compote into glass dishes, place the shortbread and the chocolate covered almonds on the side. This can be served with either ice cream, double cream or clotted cream and some fresh strawberries.

ingredients.text: 50 g salted butter, melted, plus extra for greasing

instructions.text: Peel the pumpkin and discard the seeds. Cut the flesh into small chunks and place in a medium saucepan. Cover with water and bring to the boil. Put the lid on, lower the heat and simmer for 25 minutes. Drain well and blitz in a food processor until you have a smooth puree. Leave to cool.
Grease a 22 x 11cm loaf tin with a little butter. Line the base and sides of the tin with greaseproof paper.
Preheat the oven to 180C/ gas mark 4.
Weight 280g of the pumpkin puree and place into a large bowl. Add the butter, sugar, nutmeg adn eggs and mix all the ingredients together.
Sift the flour, baking powder and salt into a second large bowl and make a well in the centre.
Pour the pumpkin mixture into the well and, with a wooden spoon, stir together until the mixture is smooth. Finally, fold in the walnuts.
Pour the mixture into the prepared loaf tin and bake in the middle of the oven for 1 hour. Once cooked and golden, the loaf will shrink from the sides of the tin.
Allow the loaf to rest for 3 minutes out of the oven before turning it out onto a wire rack to cool.
Serve this delicious bread with your favourite cheeses.

ingredients.text: 8 thin sausages, fried or baked in the oven

instructions.text: Fry the sausages in a pan, until browned and cooked through. Alternatively, cook them in the oven.
Place the halved cherry tomatoes in a bowl with the chives, salt and pepper. Mix and allow to stand until needed.

Melt half the butter in a saucepan, pour in the beaten eggs and stir until the eggs are softly scrambled, then stir in the remaining butter. Allow to stand for 2 minutes off the heat until fully cooked.
Cut the end of the bread rolls and hollow them out. Stuff the rolls with scrambled eggs, sliced sausages and the tomato mixture. Serve and enjoy!

ingredients.text: 1.5-2kg beef shin, cut into large cubes
750 g carrots, chopped into large chunks
750 g parsnips, chopped into large chunks
1 rosemary sprig, leaves removed and finely chopped

instructions.text: Heat the olive oil in a pan and add the beef, brown on all sides. Remove from the pan and set aside.
Add the onions and garlic and cook until softened. Add the rosemary sprigs.
Return the beef to the pan, sprinkle over 2-3 tablespoons of plain flour. Stir to coat the meat.
Cook for 2-3 minutes, stirring occasionally. Pour over the ale and season with salt and pepper.
Cook for 3-4 hours in a low heat oven (160C/Gas 2) with the lid on. Check from time to time that the liquid has not evaporated completely. If required, add more ale.
Add the carrots and parsnips to the stew and return to the oven for another hour.
Sift the flour into a large bowl and stir in the suet, salt and rosemary.
Gradually add the water and knead into a dough. Divide the mixture into 6 equal parts and form into dumplings.
Bake on the top shelf of the oven for the final 25 minutes of the beef cooking time.
Place the slow-cooked beef and vegetables on a plate with one of the dumplings (per person).
Dry fry the pancetta until golden and crispy, remove and set aside.
Rub the scallops in a small portion of the olive oil and sprinkle over salt and pepper.
Fry the scallops in the same pan used for the pancetta until they are caramelised, then flip over. Remove from the pan.
Take the pan off the heat and pour in the balsamic vinegar and the remaining olive oil to make the dressing.
Put the chicory, radicchio, chilli and grapes in a bowl. Add the pancetta and scallops and pour over the dressing. Serve immediately.

ingredients.text: 1 thumb size piece of ginger, peeled and roughly chopped

instructions.text: In a pestle and mortar, grind together the coriander seeds, fenugreek, turmeric, chilli, ginger, black pepper and cumin.
Toast the spices in a hot dry pan, taking care not to burn them.
Once the spices have released their aroma, drizzle over the olive oil and stir in the garlic.
Cut the goat shoulder into bite size chunks, season with salt and pepper, and add to the pan. Once browned all over, add in the tomatoes and onions.
Reduce the heat, cover the pan and cook slowly for 3-4 hours until the meat is tender. Add water if it becomes too dry.
Serve with lime wedges, boiled rice and chopped coriander.

ingredients.text: 1 medium side of salmon, skin on, pin boned

instructions.text: Soak the cedar planks for 20 minutes and heat the barbecue for indirect cooking (so front burner on, back two off).
Place the salmon on the plank, and season well with salt and pepper.
Make a slit down the centre of the salmon and spoon the butter into the crevice. Smear over the mustard and parsley.
Place the plank away from the heat source in the barbecue and cook for 6-8 minutes - check it, as it may take slightly longer but do not overcook.
Once the fish is just cooked, remove from the barbecue and squeeze over the lemon and serve straight away.

ingredients.text: 1 cucumber, peeled, halved and roughly chopped
Handful of mint leaves, finely chopped
1 melon, de-seeded and cut into cubes
200 g blue cheese, cut into small cubes

instructions.text: Assemble the salad and toss the ingredients together.
Whisk together the dressing ingredients and drizzle over the salad. Serve immediately.

ingredients.text: 500 g venison (tender-loin or shoulder), cut into bite size pieces
A few sprigs of thyme or rosemary

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4.
Heat the oil in the pan and sear the venison. Remove from the pan and set to one side.
Add the bacon to the pan, fry for 2 minutes.
Add a knob of butter, then stir in the garlic, thyme or rosemary and the onions.
When the onions have softened, add the mushrooms. Cook for 2 minutes.
Sprinkle the flour all over and cook for a further 2 minutes.
Pour over the red wine, a little at a time and stir well. Bring to boil and simmer for a couple of minutes until it thickens. Stir in the red currant jelly and season to taste.
Turn off the mixture and add in the venison, divide into individual pie dishes.
Roll out pastry and cut out discs, slightly bigger than the pie dishes, lay over the dishes to form a lid. Brush the pastry with milk or beaten egg. Cook in the preheated oven for 20 minutes.
Serve the pie with boiled potatoes and green beans, tossed with buttery chestnuts (melt the butter, add the chestnuts and warm through).

ingredients.text: 300 g mixed mushrooms, cut into thin strips
2 tbsp gourmet mushroom infused olive oil, or regular olive oil

instructions.text: Toast the bread.
Heat pan until hot, add the oil and fry the mushrooms until golden.
Add the thyme and garlic. When the garlic has slightly coloured, add the cream.
Season and allow to heat through for a couple minutes before spooning over the toast.

ingredients.text: Salt and black pepper, to taste

instructions.text: Use tinned beans or soak dried beans overnight and the boil for 1 and half hours.
Heat the olive oil in a pan and fry the red onion, tomatoes, jalape√±o, paprika and black pepper. Cook until the onions are soft.
Add the beans and the red wine and simmer for 20 minutes.
Remove from the heat and using a potato masher, mash the ingredients together, leaving some texture.
Leave to cool until just warm, not hot. Stir in the cheese, red onion and sour cream.
Sift the flour, baking powder and salt into a bowl.
Add in the melted butter and rub the mixture together using your fingertips.
Pour in the boiling water a little at a time and using a flat knife, start to combine the ingredients so it begins to form a dough.
Use your hands to knead the dough into a ball. Leave to rest for 10 minutes.
Divide the mixture into equal amounts and roll out until very thin.
Fry in a teaspoon of oil until golden brown on both sides. Serve while warm.

ingredients.text: 1 green chilli, de-seeded and finely chopped

instructions.text: Mix all the ingredients together and leave in the fridge until you're ready to serve.

ingredients.text: 4 medium-sized lean pork chops (if you don‚Äôt need to keep this super-healthy then buy pork chops with an even piece of fat around the edge for more flavour)
2 garlic cloves, peeled and thinly sliced
2 heads of pak choi, leaves separated from the root
1 red pepper, seeds removed and cut into strips
10 mange tout, cut into thin strips

instructions.text: First make the marinade. Crush 1 clove of garlic and place into a bowl with the fish sauce, oyster sauce, soy sauce, honey, orange juice and seasoning and mix. Add the pork chops and marinate for 2 hours.
Preheat the oven to 180C/ gas mark 4.

Remove the pork and set aside the marinade. Brush with oil then place onto a preheated griddle pan and cook for 2 minutes on one side, then turn and cook for a further 2 minutes on the other side. Place on a tray and finish cooking in the oven for a further 3-4 minutes. Remove and allow to rest for 3-4 minutes.

Meanwhile preheat a frying pan with a tablespoon of sesame oil and cook the remaining 2 garlic cloves for 30 seconds - ensure you cook on a gentle heat so as not to get any colour on the garlic. Add the pak choi, turn the heat up and cook for 1 minute. Add the sesame seeds.
In a separate pan, heat the sunflower oil. Once hot, add the ginger and red pepper and cook for 1 minute. Next add the mange tout and half the reserved marinade and cook for a further 1 minute.
To serve, place the pak choi onto the centre of the plate, then the pork chop and then spoon over the red pepper and mange tout mix over the top. Sprinkle over some chopped coriander to finish.

ingredients.text: 100 g chilli chocolate, broken into pieces
150 g tomatoes, skinned, de-seeded and diced

instructions.text: Using a pestle and mortar; crush the almonds, coriander seeds, cinnamon, cloves, onion sesame seeds, red chillies, Pasilla chillies, sesame seeds, raisins and the garlic.
Grind together to form a paste.
Heat the oil in a pan and cook 2/3 of the paste for 5-10 minutes on a low to medium heat.
Add in the tomatoes.
Once the aromas are released, pour in the chicken stock.
Stir and bring to the boil, mix in the chilli chocolate and allow to melt.
Put to one side and leave to infuse overnight.
Sieve to form a smooth sauce before reheating and serving.
Slice the beef into strips across the grain. Rub with the remaining 1/3 of the rub. Season with salt and pepper. Allow to marinade for at least an hour.
Just before you are ready to serve, heat a little oil in a pan and fry the strips of beef in a hot pan for 2 to 3 minutes. Serve with the heated mole sauce.
Peel the pears and stand them up in a pan that only just fits all six of them.
Pour over the plum liqueur and add the cinnamon stick.

Leave to poach gently on a low heat for 30-35 minutes until soft. Take the pears out of the liquor, and discard the cinnamon stick. Reduce until it is thick and syrupy. Remove from heat and allow to cool.
Place a meringue on a plate, put a dollop of whipped cream on it and place the pear on top. Drip the plum/pear liqueur over the pears. Serve.

recipes.title: Steamed fish coated in green chutney

ingredients.text: 4x 150 g thick, firm white fish fillets (loin of cod, fillet of sea bass, pomfret, hake and swordfish are all suitable)
100 g freshly grated coconut or 75g desiccated coconut
1 large bunch roughly chopped coriander, using the stalks
Banana leaves or foil to wrap the fish

instructions.text: Preheat your oven to 190C/375F.
Wash and drain the fish and dry with kitchen paper. Cut the fish into individual serving sizes and season lightly with salt. Set aside.

Using a food processor or blender, grind together the chillies, coconut, coriander, mint, cumin seeds, garlic, sugar and lime juice into a thick paste, adding a small amount of water if required. Adjust seasoning.

Coat each fish with the paste on both sides. Remove the stems from the banana leaves and cut into squares large enough to wrap the fish and secure gently by tying them with string, or, using the strings from the banana leaf. Alternatively kitchen foil can be substituted. If you are using foil then grease the foil lightly with some oil to prevent the fish from sticking.

Place the fish on a metal rack in a baking tray with enough water to cover the base whilst leaving the rack clear. Place the fish parcels in the preheated oven and steam bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the fish is cooked and flakes.
If using banana leaves, remove the strings and serve the fish in the banana leaf. Serve with lentil and rice pilau.
Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4 and line two muffin trays with 20 paper muffin cases.
Melt the butter or margarine in a small frying pan over a medium heat and add the sweetcorn, letting them sweat for 1‚Äì2 minutes. Set aside.
Your child/ren could help with this step. Sift the flour and baking powder into a large bowl and stir in the sugar and polenta.
Whisk the eggs. Add them to the dry ingredients along with the milk, soured cream, sweetcorn and melted butter or margarine. Stir gently to combine.

Spoon the mixture carefully and equally into the paper cases. Bake for 20‚Äì22 minutes in the preheated oven until golden and a skewer or toothpick comes out clean. Leave to rest still in the hot trays for another 10 minutes, on top of the hob (out of reach of kids).

Take each corn cake out of the tin and leave to cool completely on a wire rack. Ask a child to combine the brown sugar and cinnamon in a small dish, then, using their fingers, dust a small amount over the cooled cakes before serving. This step could also be done while the cakes are actually cooling.
Optional change for grown-ups:

Skip the spicy topping, replace the sugar for approx 75g grated hard cheese, stir-fry the sweetcorn with some chopped onion and chopped red chillies and serve warm with Mexican chilli as a ‚Äòbread‚Äô side dish.

ingredients.text: 200 ml semi-skimmed milk with 100ml water added

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 200C/Gas 6.
Sift the first 3 ingredients in a large mixing bowl. Add the milk-water mix.
Stir with a metal spoon to allow it to come together - then tip onto a lightly floured surface. If some of the mix doesn't combine, simply add another dessert spoon of milk.
Gently knead for a minute or two. Divide in half and pat down into two rounds, each measuring approximately 10cm across.
Lightly flour both loaves and then put on a baking tray. With a sharp knife, score a cross down into each (not cutting as far as the bottom).
Bake for 30 minutes. Either serve warm from the oven (it'll be softer) of leave for half an hour or so to harden up slightly. Slice and use to make your kid's sandwiches for school.

ingredients.text: .25-.5 tsp cayenne pepper (or .25 tsp cayenne and .25 tsp cinnamon)

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to220C/Gas 7.
Get your child to whisktogether the oil and spice(s)in a small bowl.
Place the wraps one on top of the other and with kitchen scissors cut into halves, then quarters, then eighths ‚Äì so you have 16 triangle shapes. Older kids could do the cutting whilst supervised.
Place the triangles on a baking tray (either 2 or 1 big one) and ask a child to brush each shape with the oil-spice mix on both sides.
Bake for about 4‚Äì5 minutes until crispy and golden. Leave to firm up a bit on the baking tray,then place on a plate with kitchen towel to cool and drain off any excess oil.

ingredients.text: 100 g split yellow peas, soaked overnight
1 L good quality, hot vegetable stock
Thin end of 1 butternut squash, peeled and chopped

instructions.text: Drain the peas and ask a child to rinse them through withcold water. Set aside.
In a large saucepan, melt the butter and the oil. Saute the onion for a couple of minutes. Add all the vegetables and stir round for another minute or so ‚Äì notice the smells and colours.
Add the split peas and pour over 800 ml (1¬º pints) of the hot stock. Stir and simmer rapidly for about 40 minutes, stirring occasionally.

Transfer to a blender or food processor and blitz until smooth. Transfer the soup back to the saucepan. Is it too thick for you or just right? Feel free to top up slightly (and stir through) with the stock you‚Äôve held back.
Serve with crusty bread and enjoy.

ingredients.text: 100 g frozen peas, defrosted (but still cold and firm)
75 g cream cheese (low-fat if you prefer)

instructions.text: The quick and easy way is to shove everything into a blender or food processor and blitz. Ta-da!

OR ‚Äì and I have done this ona few occasions ‚Äì you can get a child to measure everything out, put it in a bowl and mix, then ‚Äòscrunch‚Äô it all together with their (clean) hands. Works just as well ‚Äìand you can get them to lick their fingers afterwards ‚Äì but boy is it messy.
Serve with vegetable crudit√©s or my tortilla chips.

ingredients.text: 3 garlic cloves, to rub on the skewers
4 corn of the cob, cut into 1.5-cm pieces
2 red onions, cut through the base

instructions.text: Peel the garlic and rub over the skewers, this adds a nice garlic flavour. Chop the remaining garlic and put in a bowl.
Cut your vegetables into large chunks, leaving the mushrooms whole.

Put all the cut vegetables in the bowl with the garlic and pour some oil over to coat. Add the chopped mint and toss to thoroughly coat all the vegetables. Assemble on the skewers and grill until brown and softened.

ingredients.text: Crushed sea salt and freshly ground black pepper

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 220C/425F/gas mark 7.
