Cook the rice by placing it into a saucepan and covering with the coconut milk, and just a small amount of water. Simmer gently for 30 minutes until the rice has softened and a mixture that resembles a very firm risotto forms. Stir in the desiccated coconut and mix well.
The next step is to cook the vegetables. Start by saut√©ing the garlic in a little olive oil. Add the rest of the vegetables, and stir fry for about 10 minutes.
Remove the salmon from the marinade, and pan-fry in a tiny amount of olive oil for about 15 minutes. Turn frequently.
Place your eggs and sugar in a heat-proof bowl and place over a pan of boiling water.
Using a hand whisk, whisk ingredients together for about 7 minutes - the mix should treble in size and become pale in colour.
Sieve the flour and salt into the bowl of egg/sugar mixture and fold gently, keeping in as much air as you can.
Line the bases of your tins and butter the sides well and coat in flour, discarding any excess.
Divide the mixture up between your tins and bake at 170C (fan assisted) for 25 minutes.
Leave the sponge to cool slightly in your tins before attempting to release. Leave the sponges to cool - when cooled divide each one in half.
Whisk up your cream and fold in the strawberry puree, keeping it rippled rather than pink!
Place a good layer of cream on the base and place blueberries and raspberries around the edge. Place another layer of sponge on the top and repeat.
Place the final layer of sponge onto the top and cut the strawberries in half and place decoratively on the top. Dust with icing sugar and serve.

recipes.title: James's rich chocolate and almond cake

ingredients.text: 250 g good-quality dark chocolate, minimum 70% cocoa solids
150 g unsalted butter, cut into small pieces, plus extra for greasing

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 190C/350F/gas mark 5. Lightly grease a 23cm spring form cake tin.
Melt the chocolate and butter together in a heatproof bowl placed over a saucepan of gently simmering water. Stir until combined then leave to cool.
Whisk the egg yolks with the sugar until light and fluffy. Gradually pour the melted chocolate into the egg mixture, stirring constantly. Using a large spoon, fold in the ground almonds.

Put the egg whites into a clean dry bowl and whisk until they form stiff peaks. Using a large metal spoon, fold the egg whites into the chocolate mixture until they are just combined. Pour the mixture into the prepared tin and bake for 35 minutes. The cake will be very moist in the middle but resist cooking it for longer.
Remove the cake from the oven and leave to cool completely in the tin.
Preheat the oven to 180C.
Butter 2 cake tins, approximately 20cm in diameter.
Cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy, then slowly add the beaten eggs a little at a time.
Fold in the sifted flour, then spoon the mixture into the greased tins.
Place into the preheated oven and bake for approximately 20 minutes.
Remove from the tins, and place onto a cooling rack.
Whip the double cream until stiff, spread the jam over one of the sponges, then the cream, then the other sponge.
Dust with icing sugar then serve.

ingredients.text: 1 thick English muffin, cut in half
Lemon juice, salt and pepper to taste

instructions.text: Put the vinegar in a small pan with the peppercorns and bay leaf. Reduce over a high heat until there is only 1 tablespoon left. Strain the peppercorns and the bay leaf from this reduction.
Put the egg yolks in a bowl with the vinegar reduction.
Place the bowl onto a saucepan half filled with simmering water (bain Marie) and whisk thoroughly until the eggs have doubled in size and are light and fluffy.
Gently melt the butter so that the butter solids fall to the bottom of the saucepan.
Remove the white fats from the top of the butter then ladle the butter (a small amount at a time) onto the cooked egg yolks until the butter has all gone and the sauce starts to thicken.
If the sauce is too thick, add a little hot water.
Season to taste with salt and pepper and a little lemon juice.
Cut the muffin in half then toast until golden brown and spread with butter.
Place the 2 pieces of the muffin into the centre of a plate, warm the salmon slightly under the grill or oven and place on top of the muffin.
Place the 2 hot poached eggs on top, then spoon over the hollandaise sauce, sprinkle with cayenne pepper and chopped chives garnish with picked watercress.

ingredients.text: 300 ml double or whipping cream, whipped until thick

instructions.text: Lightly oil the Swiss roll tin and line with a sheet of baking parchment.
Whisk the egg whites until stiff but not dry. Add the sugar, 1 tsp at a time, and continue to whisk, until all the sugar has been incorporated and the mixture is stiff and glossy.
Spoon the meringue into the lined tin and tilt to level the surface. Sprinkle over the flaked almonds.
Bake near the top of a preheated oven at 200¬∞C (180¬∞C fan, Gas 6) for about 8 minutes until the top is golden brown.
Reduce the oven temperature to 160¬∞C (140¬∞C fan, Gas 3), and continue baking for 10 minutes or until the meringue is firm to the touch.
Remove the meringue from the oven and turn out on to a sheet of baking parchment. Peel the lining paper from the base and leave the meringue to cool for 10 minutes.
Spread the whipped cream evenly over the meringue, and scatter the strawberries over the cream.

Roll up the meringue from a long side, using the lining paper to help lift it. Wrap the roulade in baking parchment and leave to chill in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes. Lightly dust with sifted icing sugar before serving.

recipes.title: Succulent chicken with air-dried ham and stilton dressing

ingredients.text: 4 long slices air dried ham (preferably British)
2 tbsp very finely chopped raw carrot
2 tbsp very finely chopped dessert apple such as Cox
½ red onion, very finely sliced
150 g Cropwell Bishop Stilton, crumbled or forked, but not a mush

instructions.text: Make the dressing by whisking the mustard with a pinch of salt, sugar and pepper.
Add the vinegar then drizzle in the olive oil.
Next add the chopped carrot, apple, parsley and onion and really mix well.
Finally add the cheese, and then leave for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Carefully wrap a slice of air dried ham around each chicken breast.

Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a saut√© pan and dust the breasts with the cracked pepper. Add the wrapped chicken and cook slowly for about 20 minutes, turning occasionally, so that the chicken cooks thoroughly and the air dried ham crispens.
Serve sliced on top of some sliced endive and a little watercress. Drizzle over the dressing and serve warm.

ingredients.text: 900 g boneless shoulder of lamb (or neck)
225 g boneless shoulder of lamb (or neck)
225 g boneless shoulder of lamb (or neck)
225 g leeks, cut into coarse slices

instructions.text: Trim and cube the lamb meat.
Discard the fatty film, and place the lamb into a heavy casserole with the water, barley and a little salt.
Bring to the boil, just, skim off the surface of scum and fat, and then simmer for 30 minutes.
Add half of the potatoes. Simmer for another 30 minutes, and then stir up the pot quite vigorously to break them up.
Add the rest of the vegetables and the thyme. Simmer for approximately another 30 minutes or until the meat and vegetables are all tender.
Add the cream, butter, and parsley, reheat quickly, and serve.

recipes.title: White Chocolate and Fresh Berry Clafoutis

ingredients.text: 4 scoops of Carte D'Or Cr√®ma di Mascarpone Ice Cream

instructions.text: Grease four ramekins with the butter. Wash the berries and put them in a small bowl. Pour over the brandy and leave to marinate for 1 hour.
Preheat the oven 180¬∞C/ 160¬∞C fan assisted/ Gas Mark 4.
Heat the milk and white chocolate in a small pan until the chocolate has melted.
Whisk together the eggs, flour, sugar and vanilla extract and then gradually whisk in the milk and white chocolate mixture.
Divide the marinated berries between the greased dishes or dish and pour over the batter.
Place in the oven on a baking tray and cook for 35 - 40 minutes.
Scoop a ball of Carte D'Or Cr√®ma di Mascarpone Ice Cream onto the berry clafoutis.
Serve sprinkled with icing sugar.

recipes.title: Squash gnocchi with butter and sage sauce

ingredients.text: 700 g large floury potatoes, such as King Edwards
200 g plain flour, plus extra for rolling

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 200C/ fan oven 180C/ gas mark 6.

Peel the butternut squash and dice the flesh. Place the squash on a baking tray and scatter with sage, olive oil and sea salt. Cook for 30 minutes, until tender. Remove the squash from the oven, discard the sage and press through a potato ricer into a bowl.

Meanwhile, cook the unpeeled potatoes in a large pan of boiling salted water for 30 minutes, until soft. Drain and allow to cool slightly. When the potatoes are cool enough to handle peel them and mash or press through a potato ricer into the same bowl as the squash. Season with salt then beat the egg yolks and flour into the potatoes and squash, a little at a time, to form a smooth, slightly sticky dough.

Tip the dough onto a well-floured board, then roll into long sausages about 1cm (¬Ω inch) thick. Cut into 2cm (3/4 inch) long sections with a spatula. Place each piece on a fork and press down with your thumb and roll onto the board, leaving grooves on one side of the gnocchi.
Heat the vegetable stock in a large pan and cook the gnocchi by dropping them, in batches, into the stock for about 5 minutes ‚Äì when they float to the surface they are ready.

While your gnocchi are cooking, make the sauce. Melt the butter in a pan and heat gently until the butter becomes a light golden brown colour. Add the sage and remove from the heat, then add the lemon juice. Take the gnocchi from the stock and add to the sage sauce, adding a little of the stock as well. Toss together and then add the cheese. Toss again and serve immediately with cheese.

Add a small amount of olive oil to a large saucepan. Cut the red onion into thin slices, add to the oil and saut√© until they begin to soften. At this point, add the honey, and continue to cook until the onion takes on a caramelized texture.
Roll out the ready-made puff pastry, to a size that is large enough to fit a 25 cm/10 inch round tart tin. Once rolled out, line the tin with pastry, and trim as necessary.
Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/Gas Mark 6. Begin by blind baking the pastry, covering the pastry with grease proof paper and filling with ceramic baking beads, or even some dried beans.

Once the pastry has been blind baked for about 10 minutes, remove the baking beads and paper to reveal the pastry case. Add the caramelized onions first, ensuring the whole base of the pastry case has been covered. Then dice the cooked beetroot, and sprinkle over the top of the onion layer. Lastly, break the cheese up into little pieces all over the beetroot (beet) and onion mixture.
Return to the oven for around 10 minutes, or until the pastry is golden brown and the cheese is softening and beginning to get a few brown edges.
Serve with a side salad.

ingredients.text: 300 ml cold strong black coffee, preferably espresso

instructions.text: Pour the coffee into a large bowl, mix in 3 tablespoons of the Amaretto and set aside.

Beat the egg yolks and sugar in another large bowl for about 5 minutes until thick and pale. Add the mascarpone cheese and beat thoroughly to mix. Use a metal spoon to gently fold in the whipped cream.
Beat the egg whites in a third large bowl until soft peaks form. Fold them quickly, but gently, into the cream mixture, and then add the remaining liqueur, trying not to lose the volume.

Dip each biscuit into the coffee for just 2 seconds and no longer, otherwise they will go soggy. Drain and use to cover the bottom of a glass dessert bowl about 8cm across. Spread some of the cream mixture over the biscuits. Repeat the process.
Smooth the surface, cover with cling film and chill for about 2 hours to allow the flavours to develop.
Just before serving (and not before or the cocoa powder will go bitter), remove the cling film and dust with cocoa powder.

ingredients.text: 2 garlic cloves, crushed or a tbsp of fresh basil, depending on whether you want garlic or basil mayo

instructions.text: To make the aioli, put the egg yolk, garlic and lemon juice in a food processor with a pinch of salt. Blitz for one minute to combine.If you would like basil mayo instead of garlic, replace the garlic with a tbsp of fresh basil.

Pour the oils into a jug. With the processor running gradually add the oil through the funnel, initially to incorporate about a third. Then slowly increase the stream of oil until all the oil is added and the aioli has thickened.
Add salt and white pepper; add a little water to loosen if necessary. Store in the fridge for up to a week.
Spread the aioli on the bread and place the rest of the ingredients between the bread.

ingredients.text: 5 large Bramley apples, peeled and roughly chopped not too small
Juice and finely grated zest 1 large lemon

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 190C.
Heat a saucepan, add the butter and melt.
Add the chopped apples, sugar, lemon zest and juice and cook for a couple of minutes until they start to break down, then tip into a bowl and cool. Taste and add more sugar if needed.
Add the cornflour or arrowroot once cooled and mix well.
Line a 24cm loose bottomed baking tin with one of the discs, carefully.
Add the apple: really fill up the base and then lightly egg the top edge.
Top with the other disc of pastry, thumb up and crimp decoratively.
Brush the top with egg and sprinkle with granulated sugar, then place into the preheated oven.
Cook for 35-40 minutes or until golden.
Cool slightly and turn out before cutting.

ingredients.text: 175 g chocolate biscuits (bourbons or chocolate hob nobs are good)
1 piece of crystallized ginger, finely chopped
50 g butter - melted but not warm
3 unwaxed oranges, grated, segmented and juiced
1 orange, peeled, zested and cut into thin strips then cooked in water until tender

instructions.text: Place the chocolate biscuits into a bowl, and, using the end of a rolling pin, bash them until they resemble breadcrumbs. Add the melted butter and ginger and mix together.
Place into a 20cm spring form cake tin and press firmly into the base. Place into the fridge to set.
Meanwhile beat together the cream cheese, mascarpone, grated orange zest and caster sugar until smooth. Mix in half of the diced segments.
Whisk the double cream until thick and mix into the orange and cream cheese mixture. Spoon the filling into the biscuit case. Level the top and chill for a minimum of 4 hours until it is set.

Warm up the juice of the oranges and 50g sugar. Once hot remove and add 2 leaves of soaked gelatine, and allow to cool slightly. Pour over the top of the mousse to create a glaze and allow to set in the fridge.
Cut a wedge and garnish with the reserved segments and the cooked orange zest strips.
Grate the potatoes into some kitchen towel and squeeze out the excess moisture.
Grate the onion and add to the potato, then add the egg. Season with salt and pepper, then add the flour ‚Äì and just mix it all up! In the New York Deli, the chefs wear gloves and use their hands.
When your Latkes are browned on one side, flip them and brown the other.
When golden brown all over, remove from the pan and drain on a paper towel.
Serve with sour cream, or apple sauce. You could also serve with smoked salmon and a slice of lemon.

recipes.title: Chicken and vegetable pie with lemon zest

ingredients.text: 10 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for oiling
1 yellow pepper, trimmed, deseeded and cut into 2cm cube
1 leek, trimmed, cut lengthways then finely sliced
1 courgette, trimmed, cut lengthways than sliced 1cm thick
2 skinless, boneless chicken breasts cut into 3cm cubes

instructions.text: Brush a 25cm diameter fluted, loose based, flan tin with oil and preheat the oven to 180C/gas mark 4.

Pour 5 tablespoons of oil into a large frying pan and start to fry the onions on a medium heat for 2 minutes. Add in the rosemary with the rest of the vegetables, season with salt and pepper and continue to cook for a further 8 minutes, stirring occasionally. Remove everything from the pan with a slotted spoon and set aside.
Place the chicken pieces in a large bowl and tip in the flour. Coat the chicken evenly, tap off any excess flour and set aside.
Pour the remaining oil into the same frying pan used to cook the vegetables and fry the chicken pieces until golden and brown on all sides. Once ready set aside with the vegetables.
In a medium-sized bowl, whisk together 1 egg, the parmesan cheese, lemon zest and cream. Season with salt and pepper.

Line the bottom of the flan tin with one sheet of the ready-rolled puff pastry and arrange the vegetables and the chicken on top. Pour over the egg mixture and cover with the remaining pastry sheet. Pinch the edges together to secure and trim if necessary.
Beat the remaining egg in a bowl and brush over the pie. Make a little cut in the centre of the pastry to allow the steam to escape.
Bake in the middle of the oven for 30 minutes until beautiful and golden.
Remove from the oven and allow the pie to rest for 2 minutes before unmoulding - it will be easier to cut into slices.
Serve warm with a mixed salad of your choice.

ingredients.text: 200 g tin of green pitted olives (anchovy-stuffed are best)
Finely grated zest and juice of 1 lemon
2x 120 g tins of sardines in olive oil, drained
Large handful of fresh parsley, chopped

instructions.text: Whizz the bread in a food processor into crumbs.
Heat 2 tablespoons of the oil and gently fry the breadcrumbs until golden.
Cook your pasta following the pack instructions, then drain.

Break up the sardines with a fork and mix with the drained spaghetti, parsley, olives, lemon zest and juice plus the remaining 2 tablespoons of oil. Sprinkle the breadcrumbs on top. Season and serve with a great salad.

ingredients.text: 1 kg trimmed flank or shin of beef
1 medium sized onion, peeled and finely chopped
60 g butter, chilled and coarsely grated

instructions.text: Cut the meat into roughly 3cm sized cubes. Season half of the flour with salt and pepper and use to dust the meat. Heat the oil, and then fry the meat in 2-3 batches until golden brown, set aside.

Add a knob of butter to a large pan. Fry the onion, pancetta and garlic for a couple of minutes until golden brown. Add the thyme and bay leaf then the remaining flour and tomato puree. Stir over a low heat for 2 minutes, then add the ale and hot beef stock, stirring so as not to have any lumps.

Add the beef and bring up to a simmer, cover then cook for approximately 2 hours until the meat is tender. After 1 ¬Ω hours of cooking add the button mushroom and onions, then continue for the remaining 30 minutes.
Mix the flour, thyme leaves, salt, suet and butter together in a large bowl, make a well in the centre, mix enough water (approximately 150ml) to form a smooth dough, and knead for a minute.
Spoon the cooled beef filling into a pie dishes to 1cm from the rim, add the baby onions approximately 4 per person.

Roll out the pastry ¬†to 1cm thickness and ¬†approximately 2cm larger than the pie dish, brush the edges with egg yolks. Lay the pastry over the filling and squeeze the edges onto the dish to secure in place. Allow to rest for 30 minutes.
Egg wash the top of the pie, allow to set then egg wash again, place into a preheated oven (200C/Gas 4) for 40-50 minutes (for a large one).

ingredients.text: 400 g mashed potato (either make it yourself or buy ready-made)

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4.
Heat the oil in a pan, add the beef and fry until the meat is browned (approximately 5 minutes).
Add the jar of sauce to the pan and stir until hot.
Transfer to an ovenproof dish and cover with a layer of mashed potato.
Place in the oven and cook for 35-40 minutes until golden brown.

recipes.title: Pork, apple and black pudding plate pie

ingredients.text: 30 g butter, to grease the plate
455 g cooked and shredded shoulder of pork

instructions.text: Rub the lard and butter into the flour and salt, add the water, enough to make a dough, ensuring that it's not too wet. Wrap in clingfilm and put in fridge to rest.
Heat the oil and butter. Add the onion, garlic and carrot and slowly colour.
Add tomatoes and chicken stock and cook for approximately 15 minutes.
Take meat and shred it and add to the cooking liquor.
Cut the black pudding and apple into small dice and then colour in a frying pan. Add to the liquor and bring to the boil, season and allow to cool.
Roll out half the pastry very thinly, to the size of an oven-safe plate.
Grease the plate and lay the pastry on top. Put the cooked meat on the pastry and pile high.

Egg wash the rim. Lay the rest of the pastry out over the meat. Press the rim and scallop the edges. Brush with egg wash and bake in the oven (200C/Gas 6) for 10 minutes, then at 180C/Gas 4 for a further 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4.
Heat the oil in a pan and add the sausages until browned (approximately 5-10 minutes).
Add the jar of sauce to the pan and stir until hot.
Transfer to an oven-proof dish and cover with foil.
Place in the oven and cook for 35-40 minutes.
Serve with mashed potato and seasonal vegetables.

ingredients.text: 2 eggs, and oil to cook them in
2 King Edward potatoes, cut into 3/4 inch chunks
Salt and freshly ground black pepper

instructions.text: Boil the chunks of potato in plenty of simmering, salted water for 8 minutes. When cooked, remove from the heat and drain.
Heat a large frying pan and add the butter. Add in the onions and fry until translucent. Add the drained potatoes, increase the heat and cook until they have taken some colour.

Whilst the potatoes are frying, open the tin of corned beef and mash it up with a spoon in a baking dish. Add the mustard, Worcestershire sauce and chilli oil. Season with salt and freshly ground black pepper.
Once the potatoes have taken colour, add the corned beef mixture and stir together. Reduce the heat. Add the cream and mix and then add the parsley.
Serve with a fried egg on top.

ingredients.text: 0.3x 400 g jar of chocolate hazelnut spread

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4.

Line two baking trays with baking parchment. Spread the hazelnuts out on a roasting tray and place in the oven for 8-10 minutes, or until lightly golden (don‚Äôt forget them). Leave to cool slightly, then blitz the nuts in a food processor into fine crumbs
Add the almonds, flour, sugar and butter to the food processor and whizz until it all comes together.
Roll little teaspoon-sized amounts of the mixture in your hands to make balls of dough the size of large marbles. Slightly flatten, then space out on baking trays and bake for 15-20 minutes.
Cool completely on the trays then sandwich together with a blob of chocolate spread. Store in the fridge and take out shortly before serving.

ingredients.text: ½ thumb-sized piece of ginger, grated
1 large green chilli diced, to taste (can use 2 if you like it hotter)
½ thumb-sized piece of ginger, grated

instructions.text: Place the chicken pieces into a bowl along with the marinade ingredients, cover and leave for at least two hours.
Cook on a preheated griddle pan for 2-3 minutes per side then set aside.

Melt the butter then fry the onion, garlic, chilli and ginger for 5-6 minutes, add the spices and cook for a further 3 minutes. Add the chicken to the pan along with the passata and stock, bring to the boil then cover and cook for 30 minutes.
Stir in the yoghurt before serving and season to taste.
Fry the mushrooms in some oil until golden, then add the onions and garlic and continue to cook for 5 minutes.
Add the rice to the pan along with the water, bring to the boil, cover and cook over a low heat for 30-35 minutes or until cooked through. Garnish with some fresh coriander and serve.
Preheat the oven to 110C.
Take 170g of the butter and melt in a pyrex bowl in the oven until separated. Strain off clarified butter and set aside. (You can also do this on a very low heat on the hob if you want to).
Heat a large frying pan, add a tablespoon of olive oil and cook the onion, garlic and bacon until softened. Add the chicken livers and cook until slightly browned but still soft.
Pour in the brandy and light it to burn a little of the alcohol off. Do not let the flame burn too long, just blow it out once it's caught fire for a few seconds! Cook for a further minute.
Put the mixture into a food processor or liquidiser and mix unti smooth. Add the butter and tarragon and season to taste.
Pour the mixture through a sieve and transfer into individual pots. Top with the clarified butter, which acts as a seal.
Leave to set for at least an hour.

ingredients.text: 4x 1 cm thick slices of calves liver (Theo uses livers from Limousin calves)
8 slices of smoked pancetta, cooked until crisp

instructions.text: Cook the lentils with garlic and sage in plenty of water for about 30 minutes.
Season with a squeeze of lemon and olive oil.
Cut the chard and stalks into 1cm strips, then blanch until tender. Set aside.
Soften a garlic clove in olive oil with 1 dried chilli. Add the chard and stalks and braise for 1 minute.
Pour off the excess fat, add balsamic vinegar and creme fraiche. Pour over the liver with the pancetta laid over the top.
Serve with the braised chard and lentils.

ingredients.text: 100 g Monterey jack cheese, or mild cheddar
A couple drops of hot sauce, of your choice

instructions.text: Blacken the pepper over a gas flame of under a very hot grill. Place into a bowl and cover with clingfilm, this will make the skin easier to remove. When cooled slightly, peel the blackened skin, then de-seed and very finely chop. Don't worry if some black bits remain, this will add flavour.
Cook the macaroni according to the packet instructions, drain and transfer to an oven-proof baking dish.

Fry off the chorizo, onion and garlic in some oil for around 5 minutes until softened, then add the pepper, evaporated milk, ketchup, 2/3 of the grated cheese and stir until melted. Season and add the hot sauce to taste, pour over the pasta, making sure it's well combined, then sprinkle with the remaining cheese. Bake in a preheated oven (180C/Gas 4) for 30 minutes. Once cooked, remove and leave to stand for 5 minutes before serving.

Make the dressing for the salad by whisking the mustard, olive oil and lemon juice together. Season with salt and pepper. Just before serving, dress the watercress and shallots and serve with the sliced apple and a scattering of walnuts.
Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4. Cook the macaroni according to the packet instructions (the pasta should be slightly undercooked, or al dente).
Fry the leeks in the oil for 8-10 minutes until soft. Add the frozen spinach and cook gently until defrosted.
Take the pan off the heat, tear the mozzarella and mix together with the drained pasta, creme fraiche, Dijon and cheddar. Place the mixture into an oven-proof dish.
Now, mix the breadcrumbs and parmesan together and sprinkle on top. Bake for 20 minutes until crispy and golden. Season and serve.

ingredients.text: 100 g dark chocolate (use 70 plus cocoa solids ‚Äì coarsely chopped)
420 g granulated sugar (if possible vanilla infused sugar)

instructions.text: First place your jam jars in a preheated oven at 130C for 15 minutes to sterilise. Make sure you have weighed all your ingredients and your equipment and utensils are ready.

Thinly slice the banana to around 1mm thin pieces. Transfer the banana to a large saucepan with the water and sugar. Mix well on a medium heat, stir constantly and bring the mixture to a full rolling boil (where the bubbles do not stop when you stir it). Once the mixture starts to boil, skim away any excessive scum, stirring constantly all the time.
Keep at a rolling boil for another 2 minutes, stirring constantly till the mixture becomes clearer and brighter.
Add in the dark chocolate, mix well and bring it back to the boil. Once the chocolate has melted, remove from the heat immediately and stir in the amaretto.

Ladle the hot jam into hot sterilised jars, leaving a gap of about 1-2cm from the top. The chocolate and banana jam will keep up to 3 months if stored in fridge. Once opened consume within 2-3 weeks ‚Äì if it lasts that long!

recipes.title: Chicken escalopes with parma ham and parmesan mash

ingredients.text: 8 more fresh basil leaves half ripped half shredded (optional)
Seasoning of sea salt and cracked black pepper

instructions.text: First prepare the potatoes for the mash by peeling and roughly chopping them to an equal size. Cover with water, add a pinch of salt and simmer until just tender for around 12 minutes.

Drain then dry the potatoes in saucepan on a hob for around a minute then rice with a potato ricer or mash with a masher. Add the butter and cream then sprinkle in the grated parmesan cheese. Mix well and season to taste. Cover with cling film and set aside to reheat for serving.
Preheat your oven to 180C/gas 4.
To butterfly the chicken breasts, lay them between two sheets of cling film and flatten out slightly using a rolling pin or saucepan.
Next lay out the parma ham slices into groups of two overlapped on a chopping board. Add two basil leaves to each group of ham and lay on the chicken breasts. Wrap each breast with the parma ham.
Heat a non-stick pan on a stove top, add a splash of oil and sear each wrapped chicken breast for 1 minute on both sides and transfer onto a baking tray and cook at 180C for 8 minutes.

Prick the vine tomatoes with a small knife and put on a baking tray and drizzle over the balsamic seasoning and olive oil and pop in the oven to warm through for around 8 minutes until only just softened.

To serve, heat through the mash and sprinkle in some shredded basil. Arrange on a warm serving plate by taking the chicken and slicing it in half and presenting it on the potato. Then arrange some vine tomatoes on the plate and drizzle around the tray juices and sprinkle over any remaining basil.

ingredients.text: 4 salmon fillets, skin left on, bones removed (use sea bass or trout if you prefer)

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to (180C/350F/gas mark 4). Make deep slits in the skin of the fish. This will deepen the flavour of the spices.
Make the masala by heating the vegetable oil in a pan and adding the mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Once the mustard seeds start popping, add the garlic, ginger, desiccated coconut (if using) red chilli and half the smoked paprika. Sprinkle in a little water to stop the spices from burning.
After 2 minutes, add the leeks, carrots and green beans and cook for 1 minute.
Turn off the heat and squeeze in the lemon juice. The masala should still be crunchy.
Check the seasoning and adjust with salt.
In a bowl, mix together the yoghurt, honey, dill and remaining teaspoon of smoked paprika.
Rub the outside of the fish with the marinade, ensuring you the rub it into the slits.
Stuff the inside with the masala and pop the lemon halves next to it. Wrap in foil.

Cook for 10 minutes in a preheated oven (180C/350F/gas mark 4), before opening the foil and cooking for a further 15 minutes or until the fish is cooked through. Finally squeeze over the baked lemons and serve with cucumber and mint raita.

ingredients.text: ½ cucumber, seeds removed and finely chopped
1 tbsp fresh chopped mint, and extra to garnish

instructions.text: Dry roast the cumin seeds in a frying pan on low heat, moving them around to prevent them from burning. After a few minutes they will become golden brown. Remove from the heat and crush coarsely using a pestle and mortar.

Mix all the ingredients together in a bowl, including the roasted cumin seeds and stir. Check the seasoning and add salt to taste. Garnish with freshly chopped mint and serve chilled on top of spiced stuffed fish.

recipes.title: Refried egg, chips and rice with avocado, tomato and chilli

ingredients.text: 225 g leftover thick chips, cut into 3cm pieces
½ tsp red chilli, very finely chopped
Crispy batter pieces, refried until crisp (optional)

instructions.text: Heat the oil, add the chips and spring onions and re-cook until lightly coloured.
Remove from the pan and keep warm.
Add the beaten egg to the pan and cook until really dry, then add the rice and potatoes back in and warm through. Season well.
Place the tomatoes, avocado, coriander, chilli, spring onion and lime into a bowl and mix well.
Tip on to the tomato mixture, season well and stir.
Spoon into bowls and top with the crispy batter pieces if desired.

recipes.title: Fidget pie with pea and parsley sauce

ingredients.text: 3 cox‚Äôs apples, washed (with the skin left on), quartered, cored and each quarter cut in half
2x 135 g pre-packed honey smoked ham, torn into large strips
1 large, shallow pie dish approximately 23cm diameter
5 tbsp flat leaf parsely, roughly chopped

instructions.text: Heat the butter in a shallow pan. Add the onion and cook gently over a medium heat for 5 minutes.
Stir in the apples, bay and thyme and cook for 3-4 minutes. Sprinkle over the flour, stir and cook for 1 minute.
Splash in the cider and pour in the milk. Bring up to the boil and simmer for 4-5 minutes, stirring continuously, until thickened. Add the cream and season to taste with black pepper.
Stir in the strips of ham and mustard. Pour into a large, shallow pie or ovenproof dish and set aside to cool slightly.
Preheat oven to 200C/400F/Gas Mark 6.

On a lightly-floured surface, roll out the pastry slightly larger than the pie dish. Lightly wet the rim of the pie dish with a little water. Lay over the pastry and trim to fit the pie dish. Brush well with beaten egg.

With a small, sharp knife cut a cross in the centre of the pie, place on a baking tray and cook for 25-30 minutes or until pastry is golden and puffed. Serve with creamy mashed potatoes and pea and parsley sauce.

Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a pan, add 1 chopped onion and cook over a medium heat for 10 minutes until softened. Add 175g frozen petit pois and 200ml vegetable stock and a splash of white wine. Season well, bring to the boil, reduce heat and simmer for 2 minutes. Stir in 5 tbsp of roughly chopped flat leaf parsley and cook for 1 minute.
Place all the ingredients in a blender and carefully whiz until smooth. Season to taste.
Serve the pie with pea and parsley sauce and some creamy mashed potatoes.

ingredients.text: Knob of butter or vegetable oil, for cooking
350 g skinless chicken, cooked and shredded
2 fresh corn cobs, kernels cut off (or 1 tin)
4 large handfuls of fresh clean spinach

instructions.text: Sift the flour and salt into a large bowl and make a well in the centre, crack the eggs and add 3/4 of the milk. Whisk everything together then add remaining milk, whisk until a smooth thin batter.

Heat small amount of oil or butter in non stick pan then pour off any excess hot fat. Coat the base of the pan with a thin layer of batter and cook for around 40 seconds, flip or turn with a palette knife and cook on the other side. Slide onto a plate and repeat the process and stack up pancakes between sheets of non stick baking paper until required.
Preheat the grill to medium heat.
Heat a large non stick pan to a medium heat on stove top add a splash of olive oil and saut√© the chopped shallot for 1 minute, next add the garlic and corn cornels cook for a further minute.

Add the chicken to the pan and mix then pour over the cream. Reduce by half, stirring ingredients occasionally. Next, add the sliced spring onions and season to taste. Take the mixture and fill prepared pancakes, roll into cigar shapes and lay in a gratin dish. Take the rosemary, cheese and breadcrumbs and mix together in a bowl then sprinkle over the pancakes and pop the gratin dish under a hot grill for around 2 minutes or until bubbling and gratinated.
Preheat grill to medium heat.
First heat the cream to a simmer and reduce by a third then crumble in 3/4 of the goat‚Äôs cheese and add the maple syrup, stir until the cheese is melted and set aside.
Next, heat a saucepan to a high heat and add the spinach, crushed garlic cloves, raisins, butter and a pinch of salt and stir rapidly for 30 seconds until wilted then drain onto kitchen towel.
Discard garlic cloves then arrange the spinach mixture into prepared pancakes crumble over remaining goat‚Äôs cheese and roll up into cigar shapes.
Place in gratin dish and pour over goats cheese cream, sprinkle over grated parmesan and pop under pre-heated grill for around two minutes until bubbling.

recipes.title: Twice-cooked chips with spices and fresh mint

ingredients.text: 1 tbsp fresh ginger, very finely chopped
225 g left over thick chips, cut into 3cm pieces

instructions.text: Heat the oil in a wok.
Add the spices, onion, garlic and ginger and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add the chips and mix well.
Season with salt and pepper and add a pinch of the chicken stock cube.
Add the water and cover with a lid, heat for 2-3 minutes.
Once the water has been absorbed, stir again and remove from the heat.
Add the chopped mint and serve with a blob of yoghurt on top.

ingredients.text: 1 large brioche loaf, preferably ready sliced
100 g of both white and milk chocolate buttons

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 160C/Gas 2.
Heat up the milk and double cream, with the vanilla pod (seeds and pod) and nutmeg. Do not boil.
Separately, whisk together the eggs and sugar until the sugar is dissolved.
Then pour over the milk and cream mix and whisk together.

Slice the brioche (leaving crusts on) brush with one side with the softened butter and lay (over lapping) into an oven-proof pie dish, after one layer has been done, sprinkle with the chocolate buttons and sultanas then repeat the process.
Pour over the egg and cream mix and push the top layer of brioche down so as to be submerged under the mix.
Leave to stand for 15 minutes then place into the oven for 35 minutes.
Remove, melt the apricot jam and brush over the top to glaze.
Serve with pouring cream.

recipes.title: Roast potatoes with chilli and chaat masala

ingredients.text: 1 kg medium potatoes (Maris Piper or King Edward)

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 200C/Gas 6.

Peel the potatoes and cut them into halves lengthways. Place them into a saucepan covered with cold salted water. Bring to the boil and simmer for approximately 6-7 minutes. Drain in a colander and allow to stand for a few minutes before shaking them gently. You will want to break down the edges of the potatoes to get them to go crisp during the roasting process.

In the meantime, heat your roasting tray with sufficient oil/clarified butter in the oven and toss the potatoes with the garlic, chilli flakes and half the chaat masala. Roast the potatoes for up to an hour until they are golden and crispy, basting occasionally.
Remove from the oven and sprinkle with the remaining chaat masala.

ingredients.text: 100 g smoked pancetta, cut into lardons
1 medium sized tins of chopped tomatoes
100 g parmesan cheese, shaved with a vegetable peeler

instructions.text: Heat a thick bottomed pan and add a few drops of sunflower oil. Once hot, add the minced beef and pork, break up with a wooden spoon and cook until dark brown and nearly crisp and all the fat has dissolved (approximately 10-15 minutes).
Meanwhile, in a separate hot pan, add the smoked pancetta and cook until golden brown. Add the onions, celery and carrot and cook for a further minute.
Add the garlic, oregano, mushrooms and bay leaf and cook for a further minute. Add this to the beef and pork mix.
Add the red wine and reduce by half.
Add the tomato pur√©e and tinned tomatoes and cook for a further minute.
Add 1/2 litre of beef stock and bring to the boil, then turn the heat down to a low simmer for 1 hour. If the juices evaporate, add some more stock.
Cut the basil into thin strips and add to the sauce at the last minute.
Serve with cooked spaghetti, shaved parmesan and sprinkle with rocket leaves.
In a large frying pan, heat the oil and brown off the mutton until it's golden. You may need to do this in two batches so as not to crowd the pan too much. Remove and set aside on a plate.
In the same pan, fry the onion, celery, carrots, thyme and bay for 3 minutes.
Transfer all the meat and vegetables to a casserole dish, cover in stock and cider. Cook at 180C/Gas 4 for 3-4 hours.

Transfer the meat to a pyrex dish. Coat the sliced potatoes in butter and season. Layer the potatoes on top of the meat, overlapping until the meat is covered. Cook in the oven at 180C/Gas 4 for 25 minutes.
Remove from the oven, serve and enjoy!
Melt the butter in a big shallow pan over a medium-low heat and add the rice. Stir well to coat all the grains.
After 5 minutes, add a third of the milk and half the sugar and bring gently up to heat.
Split and scrape one of the vanilla pods and add it to the pan.
Cook for about 15 minutes, adding more milk from time to time.
Stir until al dente and the milk is used up.
Meanwhile, cut the rhubarb into 5-cm chunks and pop it in a separate pan, together with the other vanilla pod and the rest of the sugar.
Add no water, but cook on a low heat, stirring from time to time for 15 minutes, until it forms a compote. Add more sugar if needed, to taste.
Serve the rice pudding hot with the rhubarb spooned over the top.

ingredients.text: 1 tsp English mustard, or as much as you'd like
4 thick hand cut slices of cooked ham
4 very good slices of country bread

instructions.text: Make a pickle for the sandwich by finely chopping shallots, baby gherkins, pickled onions, radishes and two eating apples together, and mix thoroughly.
In a separate bowl, mix together some mayonnaise and English mustard.
Smear some of the mustard mayo onto the bread, and add some in with the pickle mixture as well. Stir to combine.
Layer a generous slice of cooked ham onto the bread, before spooning on the pickle mix. Dress the salad leaves with lemon and olive oil.
Top with the dressed salad leaves and add the top layer of bread to form the ultimate ham sandwich.

recipes.title: Sirloin steak with gorgonzola sauce and pink peppercorn

instructions.text: In a large non-stick frying pan, melt the butter with the oil and on a high heat cook the steaks with the peppercorn for 1 minute on each side. Do not season with salt.
Once ready, place the steaks on a plate and cover with foil to keep them warm. Leave the peppercorn in the frying pan.
Pour the wine in the same frying pan that you cooked the steaks and leave to sizzle on a high heat for 1 minute. Stir with a wooden spoon.
Lower the heat to medium and add the gorgonzola cheese to the frying pan. Stir constantly with a wooden spoon for 2 minutes allowing the cheese to melt and create a smooth sauce.
Once ready, place 1 steak in the middle of each serving plate and drizzle over the Gorgonzola and peppercorn sauce.
Serve immediately.

recipes.title: Chocolate cream with raspberries and orange zest

instructions.text: Melt the chocolate in a heatproof bowl over a pan of simmering water, ensuring that the base of the bowl does not touch the water. Set aside to cool but don't let it harden.
In the meantime, separate the egg yolk from the whites and place in 2 dry, clean bowls.
Whisk only 2 of the egg whites until they're stiff.
Beat the egg yolks together with the juice and zest of the orange and Amaretto liquor for 2 minutes.
With a metal spoon, gently fold the melted chocolate into the egg yolks mixture a little at the time.
Lastly, fold in the egg whites mixing all the ingredients together.
Divide the raspberries between 4 dessert glasses (each about 250ml).
Pour the chocolate mixture over the raspberries and decorate with more orange zest on top.
Serve immediately.

recipes.title: Tomato and red pepper ragout with bulgar wheat

instructions.text: Place the dried bulgar wheat into a pan and cover with water. Add the vegetable stock powder and bring to the boil.
In another pan, add the olive oil, onion, and garlic. Add a pinch of salt and saut√© until the garlic and onion are soft.
Add the chopped tomatoes and chopped red pepper, and cook until the pepper has softened and the tomatoes have broken down to become a thick sauce.

On a serving plate, place a layer of the tomato and pepper mixture into a cooking ring mould or deep round cookie cutter. Pack in tightly to around the half way mark. Then, place a layer of bulgar wheat on top, all the way to the top of the mould/cutter. Carefully remove the mould cutter to reveal a two-layer stack.
Serve with a good dense side salad.
Finely chop the onion and garlic, and slice the pepper into batons.
Saute the onion, garlic, and red pepper in a little olive oil, until the onion and pepper start to soften.
Cut the courgette into 3mm thick slice, and add to the pan.
Saute for about 1 minute, and then add in the pasata, plus a good pinch of salt and black pepper to taste.
Continue to cook until the pasata has reduced and created a thick ratatouille.

recipes.title: Shiitake mushroom and sundried tomato risotto

ingredients.text: Dash of white wine (the rest can be your treat for working so hard in the kitchen!)

instructions.text: Make up 1 litre of stock using the vegetable bouillon ‚Äì I‚Äôd advise about 1 level tablespoon of bouillon to 1 litre of water.
Finely chop the red onion, garlic, sundried tomatoes, and the celery.
Saut√© these in a large pan in a little of the olive oil with a little salt until the onion is soft and becoming transparent.
Next, add the risotto rice to the pan and stir the onion mixture and rice together. Add to this just enough stock to almost cover the rice. Allow to simmer constantly.
As the stock gets absorbed, keep topping it up until you are left with about 300ml of stock.
At this point add the shiitake mushrooms. The reason that these are added in so late is to protect their active chemicals, which can be damaged if exposed to extremes of temperature for too long.

Continue to cook in the same way ‚Äì adding stock as the rice absorbs more and more. When all the stock has gone in, add the dash of white wine (around 80ml should suffice). Allow the whole mix to cook down until the texture is close to a thick oatmeal texture, and the rice is soft. At this point add the spinach as it will wilt in seconds.
To finish, add a tablespoon of extra virgin olive oil to the mix and beat the mix until a creamy texture is reached.

ingredients.text: 1 large, dried chilli, including seeds, finely chopped

instructions.text: Melt the chocolate in a bain marie.
Stir the finely chopped chilli into the melted chocolate.
Transfer the mixture into small moulds.
Allow to set for at least two hours.

ingredients.text: 4 cm pieces of fresh ginger, grated

instructions.text: Heat the vegetable oil in a non-stick frying pan over a medium-high heat.
Add the garlic and ginger and stir fry for 20-30 seconds.
Add the pork to the pan and stir fry for 5-6 minutes.
Stir in the peppercorns, 5-spice powder and honey, along with a dash of boiling water. Mix well and bring to the boil.
Add all the remaining ingredients to the pan and cook quickly, stirring all the time for a further 3 minutes.
Coarsely Blend all the ingredients apart from the celery in a food processor to make a smooth pesto dip.
Slice the celery into crudit√©s to dip into the pesto.

recipes.title: Roasted duck with orange stuffing and honey glaze

ingredients.text: 1 large Seville orange, simmered until a skewer can be inserted with no resistance and cooled, then chopped into small pieces, pips removed
Salt and freshly ground black pepper

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 200C/Gas mark 6.
Heat the oil in a pan, add the onions and garlic and cook gently for about 5 minutes, or until soft.
Add the sage, stir well and remove from the heat then mix in the sausage meat.
Add the egg, chopped orange and breadcrumbs and mix well and season with salt and pepper.
Remove the duck from its wrapper and take out any giblets.
Season the cavity well and fill with the stuffing then tie the legs together.

Prick the bird all over with a fork (so that the fat is released when it cooks) then tear off a piece of foil, about 50cm in length and scrunch up into a flat oblong. Place the scrunched up foil in a roasting tin and sit the duck on top.
Season well and cook in the oven for about 45 minutes, then turn the heat down to 180C and cook for a further 30 minutes, or just over until cooked through.
Heat the orange juice, vinegar and honey together and reduce slightly.
Carefully remove the duck from the oven and spoon the honey glaze over the breast.
Turn the oven back up to 200C and put back in the oven and continue cooking for the final 15 minutes. The honey will make a delicious glaze but take care as it can burn easily.
When cooked, remove the duck from the oven and allow to stand for 20-30 minutes.
To serve:
Carve the duck into quarters and serve with spoonfuls of the stuffing.

recipes.title: Bream fillets in a pine nut sauce with aromatic fennel

ingredients.text: 2 large fennel heads, roughly chopped, fennel tops reserved
60 g plain flour, seasoned with salt and pepper
1 tbsp olive oil, plus more for frying

instructions.text: Top make the sauce:

Fry the anchovies in a little olive oil and add a handful of toasted pine nuts. In a separate bowl put the chilli, lemon segments, fennel tops and season with salt and pepper. Toss in the cooled anchovy and pine nut mixture and combine well together. Set aside.
For the fennel:

Saut√© the fennel, fennel seeds and garlic in the butter and olive oil. Season with salt and freshly ground black pepper, and then add the wine. Simmer very gently, covered with a lid, for 15 minutes until the fennel is nearly tender. Pour in the milk and continue to gently simmer for 10 minutes until the sauce thickens and the fennel is creamy and soft. Keep the fennel warm whilst you cook the fish.
Pat the fish fillets dry with kitchen paper and dip the fish, skin side down, into seasoned flour.
Take a frying pan big enough to take both fillets. Allow the pan to get hot before adding a little bit of olive oil.
Oil the fish a little and put the fish fillets into pan, flesh-side down ‚Äì they should sizzle immediately. If the fish arches up, put a small plate on top of the fish to hold it down.
Cook the fish for a couple of minutes, flip over and cook for a further minute on the other side.
Arrange the fennel on a plate, drizzling with a little of the milky sauce. Place a bream fillet on top of the fennel and finish with a line of the pine nut sauce along the length of the fish.

ingredients.text: 400 g shop bought ginger cake, sliced thickly
800 g forced pink rhubarb, rinsed in water and chopped approx 1- 2 inch pieces
Juice and zest from one orange
1 vanilla pod, split in half lengthways

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C.

Place slices of ginger cake in the bottom of your glasses/ramekins. Sprinkle with dark rum. (If you do not wish to use dark rum you can use the excess juice from the roasted rhubarb in the next step).

Place the rhubarb in an oven dish and grate the zest of an orange on top. Squeeze juice from orange over the rhubarb and sprinkle over caster sugar evenly. Bake uncovered for appox 15-20 mins until rhubarb is tender, not mushy and still keeps its shape. The rhubarb can then be spooned on top of the ginger cake bases.

Pour the double cream and vanilla pod in a saucepan and bring to the boil gently. Meanwhile, mix egg yolks, cornflour and caster sugar in a bowl until smooth. Once the cream and vanilla mix has come to the boil remove vanilla pod and pour the double cream into the egg yolk mix stirring continuously. Rinse out the saucepan and leave a thin layer of water at the bottom of the pan and pour custard mix back into pan. Stir over low heat until a thick consistency. As soon as the custard has thickened place the bottom of the saucepan into a bowl of cold water ‚Äì this will stop the custard curdling.
Pour the custard over the rhubarb layer.

To make the meringue, whisk egg whites until soft peaks form, then add half of the caster sugar, a spoonful at a time, whisking after each spoonful. Repeat until the first half of sugar is gone then whisk in the cornflour. Repeat whisking with remaining sugar one spoonful at a time. Be careful not to overwhisk, just ensure all sugar is combined.
Spoon the meringue mixture on top of the custard layer gently. Heat with a blowtorch or under a hot grill for 1-2 minutes until the meringue is golden.
Serve immediately whilst still warm and enjoy!

ingredients.text: Good handful of picked curley kale (enough for 4)
2 sticks celery, peeled and cut into batons
75 g good quality smoked pancetta cut into lardons (small batons)

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 200C/Gas 6.

Remove the winglet bones and other trimmings from the duck (neck gizzards). Place a drizzle of oil into a pan, then add the duck trimmings, vegetable and herbs. Cook until golden brown, moving all the time, then cover with water (approximately 1 pint). Bring to the boil, skim off any impurities and fat, then turn down the heat and cook for 1 ¬Ω hours.

In a roasting tray, add a few drops of vegetable oil, cut the apple in half and place into the centre of the bird. Add the halved onion and carrot to the roasting pan, then add the duck and colour on all sides. Place on top on the vegetables using them as a trivet, then place into the oven.
After 20 minutes, remove and baste the duck with its own fat, then turn down the oven (it should be nice a golden at this stage) place back into the oven and cook for a further 1 ¬Ω hours.
For the kale and to finish:

Add a tablespoon of duck fat to a pan and heat, add the carrot and celery batons and colour slightly. Add the curly kale which has been blanched (plunged into boiling water for 2 minutes and drained) then the white wine and cook for 10 minutes. Add the cream and cook for a further few minutes and season.

Remove the duck from the pan and allow to rest, tip away any excess fat from the pan (reserve) and place onto a high heat. Add the wine and port and scrape the bottom of the pan to lift all the duck sediment. Scoop out the centre of the apple that has been cooked inside the duck and add to the pan. Add the strained duck stock and boil until a sauce consistency is achieved and strain if necessary.

Heat the reserved fat from the cooking of the duck and add the sliced potatoes. Season and cook until golden brown, crisp and tender - this should take approximately 10 minutes. Once cooked, add the chopped thyme leaves.
Carve the duck and serve on the creamed bacon kale and pour over the roasting juices. Serve with saut√©ed potatoes and a few sprigs of watercress.

ingredients.text: 1 litre good, strong beef or chicken stock

instructions.text: Heat the oil, then add the onions and thyme then cook for 15 minutes to soften.
Add the flour and mix well, brown slightly.
Add the stock, jelly and cook gently for 20 minutes or until cooked and thickened.
Season well with salt and pepper and serve.

recipes.title: Prawns with spicy tomato sauce and feta

instructions.text: Heat oven to 200C.
Pour lemon juice over cleaned and de-veined prawns in a bowl and set aside.
Heat oil in a non-stick frying pan, saute spring onions, garlic, celery, chilli pepper, parsley and tomatoes until celery is tender. Reduce heat, and simmer for about 15 minutes.
In another pan, saute prawns in butter until they are pink.
Pour the tomato sauce mixture into the bottom of a casserole dish; top with prawns, sprinkle with oregano. Top with feta cheese and a little black pepper. Bake for 15 minutes or until feta melts.
Serve the spicy prawns with the pasta.

ingredients.text: 2 tbsp peanut butter (a good quality one without added salt or sugar)

instructions.text: Melt the honey, coconut oil, and peanut butter together in a pan.
Stir in all other ingredients and mix well, until a sticky mixture is formed.
Press the mixture into a greased baking tin (8 inches x 8 inches should suffice).
Place at the top of a hot oven (200C/gas 9) for 10 - 15 minutes or until golden brown.
Allow to cool fully before cutting into bars.
Simply whizz all the ingredients together in a juicer!

ingredients.text: 1 large handfuil of mixed green leaves
¼ inch sliced unpeeled raw beetroot

instructions.text: Simply whizz all the ingredients together in a juicer!

ingredients.text: 900 g rhubarb, trimmed and cut into 5 cm (2 inch) pieces
Ice cream or custard, to serve

instructions.text: To make the pastry, combine the flours, salt and sugar in a bowl. Rub in the butter until crumbs are formed. Add the sour cream and lime juice and keep mixing to form a dough (it won‚Äôt be smooth but this is fine). Wrap the dough in cling film and chill for 2 hours.

Preheat the oven to 200C/fan oven 180C/Gas Mark 6. Grease a 25 cm (10 inch) round tart tin. Roll out the dough to a 5 mm (¬º inch) thickness and line the tart tin; trim the overhanging edges. Prick the base of the pastry case with a fork and cover with baking paper and baking beans. Cook for 15 minutes. Take out of the oven and remove the paper and beans, then cook the pastry case for a further 5 minutes.

To make the filling, combine the sugar and water in a saucepan and cook over a low heat until the sugar dissolves. Add the lime zest and cinnamon stick and bring to the boil. Add the rhubarb, bring back to the boil, then reduce to a medium heat. Cover and simmer for about 5 minutes until the rhubarb is just soft. Remove from the heat and leave to stand for 15 minutes.
Using a slotted spoon, remove the rhubarb and set on one side. Reduce the cooking liquid by half. Remove from the heat and leave to cool slightly. Remove the cinnamon stick.
Place the rhubarb in the cooked tart case and then pour over the syrup. Cook at 180C/fan oven 160C/Gas Mark 4 for 15 minutes. Serve with ice cream or custard.

ingredients.text: 1 tsp caraway seeds, lightly crushed in a pestle and mortar
55 g low fat heart healthy spread, melted

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 200C/Gas 6.
Line a 27 x 40cm (11¬º x 16in) Swiss roll tin with non-stick baking parchment.

Using a free-standing electric mixer, whisk the eggs and caster sugar together until the mixture is very light and fluffy and almost doubled in volume. This will take about 5 minutes, so be patient with it!
Now, using either a spatula or a large metal spoon, fold in the flour, grated lemon zest, crushed caraway seeds, and melted low-fat spread. Do not overmix.

Pour the mixture into the prepared tin and bake, checking it after 12 minutes. You don‚Äôt want too much colour on the sponge, so keep a close eye on it for a maximum of 16 minutes until it is light and springy to the touch. As soon as you can see that the sponge is cooked in the middle but not browning around the edges, remove from the oven.

Allow to cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then turn out onto a sheet of non-stick baking parchment sprinkled with some icing sugar, and using the baking parchment, carefully roll up into a Swiss roll. Allow to cool.
To make the filling, mix the cheese, lemon juice and lemon curd together in a bowl.
Now, very finely slice the lemon-mint or mint leaves and mix these into the lemon curd mixture.

Only when the sponge has completely cooled, carefully unroll and spread the inside of the sponge with the lemon and mint cream. Now, re-roll the cake using the baking parchment to help keep it all together. Place on a serving dish, dust with a little icing sugar and top with the mint sprig.

recipes.title: Steamed grey mullet with simple dipping sauce

ingredients.text: 1 medium grey mullet, scaled and gutted and cut into 4 large pieces
A little fresh basil and coriander

instructions.text: Heat a medium saucepan with 300ml water, add a pinch of salt, dash of fish sauce and soy sauce, the chilli and a few herbs. Bring to the boil and simmer, lid on.
Meanwhile, stuff the cavity of the fish with a little basil and coriander, then pop into the simmering pan. The water should be roughly a third up the side of the fish. Cook for 10 minutes gently.
Meanwhile place all the ingredients for the dipping sauce into a bowl and mix well together.
Lift out the fish and serve with the dipping sauce on the side, do not overcook the fish.

ingredients.text: 250 g chicken legs/thighs/breast left over from Sunday roast, cut into large chunks
2 medium leeks, washed and diced into 2.5cm pieces
100 g cooked gammon (leftover as well if you have or you could fry up some rashers of bacon and chop them)
Good handful of chestnut mushrooms, cut into quarters
½ pint good quality chicken stock, approximately
250 g puff pastry, for the topping

instructions.text: Melt the butter in a thick bottom pan on a low heat, stir in the flour until all butter is soaked up, and gradually add the warmed chicken stock a little at a time so as not to have any lumps. Once all the stock has been mixed in, turn down the heat and allow to cook for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, if it starts to get to thick add a little more stock.
Add the double cream, and cheese, remove from the heat and allow to cool.

Preheat a frying pan with a drizzle of olive oil, add the leeks, rosemary and thyme and cook 2-3 minutes, then add the mushrooms and wine and cook for a further minute. Remove from the heat and allow to cool slightly. (The mixture should be moist not wet).
Mix the sauce, mustard, chicken and gammon ham together in a bowl (adding a little sauce at a time so as not to be too wet).
Season and place into a pie dish.

Roll out the puff pastry to 1cm thickness, place into the fridge to rest. Remove after 15-20 minutes, egg wash the edges of the pie dish and place the puff pastry on top, cut away any excess pastry from the edges, crimp the edges and egg wash the top of the pie (using only free range egg yolks) once the egg has set, repeat this process so you have a ‚Äòdouble‚Äô egg wash on top, decorate as you wish (puff pastry leaves, etc).
Place into a preheated oven (200C/Gas 6) for 25-30 minutes, until the pastry is golden brown and the centre is hot.
Serve with smooth creamy mashed potatoes.

ingredients.text: 1 head of broccoli, florets boiled and set aside for serving, stalk diced to add to the risotto

instructions.text: Drizzle olive oil in a deep sided frying pan and gently cook the broccoli stalk, courgettes, onions, garlic and fennel until soft.
Pour in the risotto rice and stir everything together. Cook for a couple of minutes until the edges of the rice grains become translucent.
Add a ladle of hot stock, stirring until the rice has nearly absorbed all the liquid. Repeat this process a second time.

Add the kidneys and white wine, stirring continuously. When the liquid is nearly absorbed, add another ladle of stock. Keep stirring and adding the stock until all the liquid has almost been absorbed and the rice is cooked through.
Stir through the cheese and tarragon. Season with salt and pepper and serve with the reserved broccoli florets.

ingredients.text: 1 broccoli head, broken into florets and the stalk roughly chopped

instructions.text: Melt the butter in a pan.
Add in the onions, garlic, broccoli florets and stalks, and allow to soften. Pour in the stock.
When all the ingredients have softened, crumble in the cheese and using an electric blender, blend all the ingredients into a pur√©e.
Finally, add in the cream and blend again until smooth.
To serve, drizzle over a swirl of cream.

ingredients.text: 1 cucumber, peeled, split down the middle and cut into 2cm chunks
2 beef steak tomatoes, cut into thick chunks (same size as the cucumber)
3 small red onions, quartered, or if larger, cut in quarters and then cut those in half again

instructions.text: Toss the cucumber, tomatoes, red onion, feta and olives together.
For the dressing, whisk together the white wine vinegar, olive oil, sugar and lemon juice.
Pour over the salad and sprinkle with chopped mint.

ingredients.text: 1 kg new potatoes, halve the larger ones

instructions.text: Place the porcini mushrooms in a heat proof bowl, just cover with boiling water and leave to soak for 15 mintues Remove the mushroom from the water and finely chop. Retain the mushroom liquor for later.
Melt the butter in a pan and gently fry the garlic and thyme for a couple of minutes. Add the chopped chestnut mushrooms.

Once the mushrooms have begun to colour and have softened add the chopped porcini and pour in the mushroom water and turn up the heat. Cook until the water has evaporated, stirring occasionally. Remove from the heat and leave to cool. Once cooled, mix with the chicken liver pate.
Rub the beef with a little olive oil and season with salt and pepper.
In a hot pan, brown the meat on all sides. Remove and allow to cool.

Lay the ham slices side by side, slightly over lapping on a chopping board. Place the fillet of beef in the centre and cover with a layer of the mushroom mixture and wrap the ‚Äòduxelle‚Äô in the Parma ham to form a parcel.

Lay a sheet of puff pastry on a large, lightly floured square of greaseproof paper. Place the beef in the centre of the pastry. Brush the edges of the pastry with a beaten egg and lay the second sheet of puff pastry over the top of the fillet and press gently around the beef.

Trim the edges leaving a 2¬Ω inch border around the fillet, then crimp together to form a well sealed parcel. The greaseproof paper allows an easy transfer of the beef Wellington to the roasting tin. Brush with a beaten egg, and place in the oven at 180C for 25 minutes, until the pastry is golden brown.

Pour the red wine and port into a saucepan, add the bay leaves and chopped shallot and leave to simmer on a low heat until it has reduced to form a thick sauce. Remove the bay leaves and shallot before serving.

Boil or steam the potatoes until tender, drain and keep warm. Melt the butter in a shallow pan, add the sage and flaked almonds and fry gently for a minute then add the chestnuts. Boil the broccoli florets for 3-5 minutes until only just tender, then drain.
To serve, gently mix the broccoli with the melted butter, almonds and chestnuts, and serve with the potatoes.

recipes.title: Stuffed pork with root vegetable dauphinoise

ingredients.text: 6 dry cured smoked streaky bacon rashers, 2 chopped and 4 left whole
4 slices of bread, blended into crumbs
½ swede, peeled and thinly sliced
1 sweet potato, peeled and thinly sliced
2 medium sweet potatoes, peeled and thinly sliced
350 ml single cream, seasoned with salt and black pepper

instructions.text: Heat a little olive oil in a pan and fry the chopped bacon, garlic, onion and fennel.
Once softened, stir in the chopped almonds. Pour over the cider and allow to cool.
Mix in the beaten eggs and finally stir in the breadcrumbs.

Next, flatten the pork fillet so that it can be stuffed. Cut the fillet down the middle lengthways, being careful not to cut all the way through, and open the fillet up like a book. To flatten it further, cover with cling film and tap it with a rolling pin.
Spread the stuffing mixture down the middle of the fillet and close the meat over the stuffing forming a long sausage shape. Sew it close with kitchen string.
Lay the rashers of bacon over the top of the stuffed pork loin. Roast in the oven at 180C/Gas 4 for 30 minutes.
Heat the sugar and butter in a pan and lay the apple rings in flat. Cook until they have turned golden on both sides. Remove and set aside.
Pour the cider into the pan and leave to reduce until it forms a sticky consistency, then return the apple rings to the pan.
Grease some ramekin dishes, or a roasting dish, with a generous amount of butter and also rub with sides with the garlic clove.
Place a layer of potato in the base of the dishes, followed by a layer of swede, then sweet potato. Continue alternating the layers to fill the dish/es.

Pour over the cream until the vegetables are just covered and season with salt and black pepper. Press the vegetables down with your fingertips, or a spoon, to release any air bubbles. Bake in the oven at 160C/Gas 2 for approximately 60 minutes.
Slice the pork and serve on the plate with some of the caramelised apples and the root vegetable dauphinoise.

recipes.title: Sea bass baked in a salt crust

ingredients.text: 2 crab shells, with some meat left on is fine

instructions.text: Place the crab shells in a pan and pour in the water. Bring to the boil and pour in the white wine.
Bash the crab shells a bit to release their flavour. Stir in a pinch of saffron, this will turn the stock a rich golden colour.
Simmer gently for 15-20 minutes. Strain the crab stock through a fine piece of muslin and discard the remains of the crab.
Return the stock to the pan and place over a gentle heat. Sprinkle in the gelatine powder and whisk until it dissolves.

Cut squares of cling film. Drape each square loosely over an egg cup making a dip in the centre. Place a half strand of saffron or small sprig of thyme into the dip and top with 1 teaspoon of crab jelly.

Carefully pull the cling film together over the jelly and twist around to form a ball, or pearl, inside the parcel. Repeat with all the jelly. Hang the cling film parcels on a line until the pearls have set.
Mix the salt with the water to form a thick paste. Spread about a third of the salt paste over the bottom of an oven proof dish.
Stuff each sea bass with lemon slices and rosemary sprigs. Place the fish on top of the salt paste. Completely cover the fish with the remaining salt mixture.
Cook the bass in a preheated oven at 200C/Gas 6 for 20 minutes. Once cooked, carefully remove the fish from the salt crust.
Unwrap the saffron crab pearls and place on top of the fish and serve with a green salad.

recipes.title: Belly of pork and black pudding

ingredients.text: 200 g black pudding, cut lengthways into thick slices (approximately 5mm)
2 slices of old bread, blitzed into breadcrumbs
500 g cooking apples, peeled and chopped

instructions.text: Place the apples in a pan and sprinkle with the sugar. Cook over a low heat until the apples have broken down to a pur√©e.
Melt the butter in a hot pan, add the carrots and toss to coat in the butter.
When bubbling, pour over the calvados and flamb√©.
Preheat the oven to 150C/Gas 2. Lay the pork belly out flat, meat side down in a roasting tray. Cook 1.5-2 hours. Allow to cool so that it can be handled.
Line a tupperware or glass container (approximately 150mm x 100mm) with cling film, leaving enough excess film to wrap over when the container is full.

Pull and slice the pork belly apart into the natural layers of meat and fat. Place a layer of the meat at the bottom of the container, filling in any gaps by pressing in excess fat. Then lay on a layer of black pudding, pressing down firmly you can 'spread' the black pudding layer out and meld it together with fingers. This pressing down will ensure that the 'sinkers' stay intact when cooking later. Repeat the layers, finishing with a layer of the pork belly.
Tightly wrap the excess cling film over the meat and place a weight on top to continue pressing the layers together. Place in a fridge and leave overnight or for at least 2-3 hours.
Remove from the fridge and carefully unwrap. Cut into 8 inch cubes.
In separate bowls, place the beaten egg, flour and breadcrumbs.
Coat the 'sinkers' first in flour, then egg, then breadcrumbs.
Heat a little oil in a frying pan on a high heat. Shallow fry the 'sinkers' until the breadcrumbs turn golden and crispy on all sides. They can be deep fried if you have a fryer at home.
Serve with the warm carrot salad, apple pur√©e and poached egg on top.

ingredients.text: 75 g smoked cheese, such as cheddar
3 thyme sprigs, or 2 tsp dried thyme

instructions.text: Sift the flour and salt into a large bowl.
Cut the cold butter into 1/2 cm cubes and add to the flour.
Using your fingertips, rub the butter and flour together until it resembles breadcrumbs. Add the water and knead briefly into a solid ball. Leave to rest in the fridge for 30 minutes.
Roll out to about 3mm thickness. Line the greased tart tins with the pastry. Lightly prick the bottom with a fork and cover with a disc of greaseproof paper, weighed down with baking beans.
Bake for 10-12 minutes at 180C/Gas 4 until golden brown.
Allow to cool for 5-10 minutes before filling.
Thinly slice the peeled onions through the root so they remain in segments. Char in a hot, dry frying pan. Allow to cool.
Beat the egg and add the milk, season.
Grate the cheese and add to the egg mixture. Stir in the thyme leaves.
Arrange the charred onions over the base of the pastry. Pour over the egg mixture to fill the tart cases.
Bake at 180C/Gas 4 for 15 minutes, or until the egg mixture is set and golden.
Allow to cool for a couple of minutes before removing from the tins. Serve.

ingredients.text: 3 yellow/green courgette, chopped into large chunks

instructions.text: Place a casserole dish, that the hogget only just fits into, on the hob and sweat the sliced onions and fennel on a gentle heat.
Add the hogget and seal the meat on all sides.
Pour over the wine, filling the dish half way.
Pop in the bouquet garni and allow to cook for 1 hour and 50 minutes, turning the hogget every 30 minutes.
When the meat is cooked, remove it from the heat and pour off the cooking liquor.
Melt butter in a frying pan, add the diced onion, cook gently and allow to soften. Stir in the flour and cook for 2 minutes.
Gradually pour in the juices and wine from the casserole dish into the pan, stirring continuously. Return to the heat and cook until thick.

Heat the oven to 180C/Gas 4. Scatter the fennel, courgette, red pepper, potatoes, garlic cloves, and rosemary sprigs over the bottom of a large roasting dish. Sprinkle with sea salt and drizzle with olive oil. Roast for approximately 40 minutes or until tender. After 25 minutes, add the cherry tomatoes and return to the oven. To finish, add a squeeze of lemon juice.
Serve thick slices of the meat on top of the vegetables and pour over the onion sauce.
Place the cucumber in a sieve and sprinkle with salt. Leave for 1 hour to allow the excess liquid to drain out.
Shake the cucumber to remove more liquid, then stir it into the yoghurt and mix in the chopped mint.
In a shallow bowl, mix the flour, garam masala, fennel, coriander and seasoning.
Slice the fillet into two thin fillets, then lightly coat the dabs with flour.
Shallow fry the fillets in olive oil until golden brown. Serve each person with a small fillet from the top and bottom of the fish.
Serve with the cool dip.

ingredients.text: 500 g new potatoes, boiled and roughly crushed
200 g green gooseberries, topped, tailed and cut into quarters
50 g light brown sugar, sweeten to taste
Zest of 1 orange, and juice of half

instructions.text: Flake the mackerel fillets into a bowl along with the garlic and parsley. Add in the crushed potatoes and combine.
Mix in the egg and flour.
Using your hands, divide the mixture into equal amounts and shape into balls that can be flattened into cakes. Place in the fridge until ready to cook.
When ready, shallow fry in butter/oil until golden brown on both sides.
Put the gooseberries, orange juice, orange zest and sugar into a pan. Cook for 25-30 minutes until thick and syrupy.
Place the fish cake on a bed of salad leaves and top with the gooseberry relish.

ingredients.text: 1.4 kg boned and rolled pork shoulder
1 punnet of plums, cut in half, stones removed
1 inch piece root ginger, roughly chopped
150 g sugar snap peas, top and tailed
2 pak choi, cut in half and sliced lengthways
1 inch root ginger, peeled and thinly sliced into matchsticks

instructions.text: Put the star anise, chopped ginger, peppercorns, nutmeg, and green chilli in to the centre of a small piece of muslin and tie to form a bundle. Put this in a saucepan with the plums and simmer gently for 15 minutes.

Tip the plums into a sieve over a bowl, remove the spice bundle and strain the plum juice into the bowl. Return the juice to heat and simmer to reduce to a sauce consistency. Sweeten with the honey according to taste.
Meanwhile, untie pork shoulder and carefully cut the meat so that you can lay the pork out flat, score the skin with a sharp knife and set aside.
Spread the cooled plums over the pork in a thin layer, roll back up and tie together with string.
Brush over with oil, sprinkle with sea salt and place in a roasting tin in the oven at 200C/Gas 6 for 1 hour and 40 minutes.
Remove the pork from the oven and leave to rest, cut off the string and carefully cut the crackling from the meat, trim the remaining fat and carve into thick slices.

Pour the oil into a hot wok, add the chilli, ginger and garlic for 10 seconds then add and stir fry the peppers, spring onions, sugar snaps, and pak choi. After a couple of minutes add the lime and the soy sauce. Finally pour over the plum syrup.
Cook the noodles as per packet instructions. Add to the stir fried vegetables and serve topped with slices of the pork and crackling.

ingredients.text: 150 g moong dal, washed and soaked in water for 30 minutes
400 g basmati rice, washed and soaked in water for 30 minutes

instructions.text: Heat a heavy-based pan until hot. Add the ghee, bay leaves, black cardamom, cumin, cinnamon sticks and cloves. Allow to crackle for a few seconds, then add the onions. Fry, stirring occasionally until the onions turn pale brown around the edges. Add a pinch of salt, the garlic, ginger,and stir well.

Drain the lentils and add to the pan with about 50ml water. Reduce the heat, cover with a lid, and simmer for approximately 10 minutes, stirring from time to time, until the lentils soften. If the mixture becomes too dry, add a little more water.

Drain the rice and add to the lentils along with 850ml hot water and 2 teaspoons of salt. Bring to the boil and cook the rice until most of the liquid has evaporated and small craters form on the surface. Lower the heat to minimum, cover with a clean dry cloth, and a tightly fitted lid. Leave for 15 minutes or so, until all the moisture has been absorbed.
Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4. Thoroughly grease a muffin baking tin.
Finely slice the leek until you have about 100g of slices.
Melt the butter in a pan and saut√© the leeks for about 2‚Äì3 minutes over a medium‚Äìhigh heat. They will break up and reduce as you stir them round but don‚Äôt worry about that.
Ask a child to sift together the flour, salt and mustard powder into a bowl. Also get them to stir through the cheese and beat the egg in a separate bowl.
Whizz up the buttery leek mix in a blender or food processor so that the leeks break up some more. Once your kids are used to eating leeks you can leave them as chunkier pieces.
Add the milk and oil to the beaten egg, then pour into the dry ingredients. Add the blitzed leeks and stir through.

Divide the mixture equally into 10 of the muffin tray holes (you can use muffin paper cases if you want) and cook for about 18 minutes in the preheated oven. Once out of the oven, leave in the tray for a further 10 minutes. Turn each muffin out to cool slightly on a wire rack. Once cooled you can freeze them individually wrapped in cling film.
If serving to grown-ups, mix together butter with garlic and parsley and serve on the side for spreading.

ingredients.text: 50 g roasted red peppers, from a jar (or roast your own if you have time)

instructions.text: Put everything in a blender or food processor and really blitz until very smooth. So your child feels involved, maybe they could help ‚Äòchop‚Äô the peppers up a bit with a plastic knife or stir all the ingredients together before blending.
