ingredients.text: 25 g cooked squash or pumpkin, peeled and cooled
150 g pineapple, skin off (or tinned as long as it's in juice and not syrup)
3 dessert spoons low-fat live yoghurt or cr√®me fraiche

instructions.text: Ask your child to help mash the cooked squash or pumpkin up a bit and also to chop the banana ‚Äì kid‚Äôs plastic blunt knives are perfect for this.
Then put all of the ingredients in the blender or food processor, blitz until smooth and serve.

recipes.title: Goat's cheese pate with apricot relish

ingredients.text: 2 gelatine leaves or 1 sachet powdered gelatine
175 g ready-to-eat dried apricots, finely chopped

instructions.text: If using gelatine leaves, place in a bowl of cold water to soak for 10 minutes to soften.

Place the cream in a small pan and bring to a simmer, then sprinkle in the gelatine and stir in the lemon juice. If using gelatine leaves, drain and gently squeeze dry, then whisk into the cream mixture for 1 minute until the gelatine has fully dissolved. If using powdered gelatine simply whisk in a thin steady stream and continue to whisk for 1 minute until dissolved.

Meanwhile, break up the goat's cheese into a bowl and add the pepper and herbs. Stir in the cream and gelatine mixture until well combined. Lay out a sheet of foil and cover with a layer of clingfilm, then spread the goat's cheese mixture into the middle and shape into a log, twisting and rolling up the foil and clingfilm to secure. Chill for at least 4 hours or overnight.

To make the apricot relish, heat the oil in a heavy-based pan and gently saut√© the onion for 10 minutes until well softened but not coloured. Add the apricots, wine, vinegar, honey and salt and bring to the boil, stirring. Reduce the heat and simmer for about 30 minutes until all of the liquid has reduced and been almost completely absorbed. Transfer to a bowl and leave to cool completely.

To serve, remove the foil and clingfilm wrapper from the pate and cut into slices. Arrange three slices in the centre of each plate and surround with spoonfuls of the apricot relish. Serve at once with a separate basket of crusty bread.
Pour 1 tablespoon of the pomegranate cordial into the bottom of each champagne flute.
Squeeze the juice of a lemon wedge into each glass then top with champagne.
Scatter in a few pomegranate seeds and enjoy!

Mix together the cream cheese and lemon juice. Spread this over each blini. Chop the smoked salmon then place a pile on top of the cream cheese mixture. Sprinkle over a little of the dill and finish with some freshly ground black pepper.
Preheat oven to 180C/gas Mark 4.
Cream the butter and sugar together in a pan.
Add 2 eggs and whisk.
Sieve flour into the mixture and using a wooden spoon and a figure of eight motion, mix together.
Divide mixture into fairy cake cases ‚Äì pop in the oven for 15-20 mins
When cooled, decorate with icing and sweets.

recipes.title: Baked brown sugar glazed ham hocks

instructions.text: Soak the ham hocks overnight in cold water. Wash them really well, then place in a deep pan.
Fill with cold water and bring to the boil. Simmer for 5 minutes, then taste the water. If it's salty, tip off the water and re-fill. If it's not not salty, you can add a little salt to the water.
Turn the heat down until the water is just simmering and cook for 15 minutes.
Skim off any foam off the surface, then add the vegetables and herbs.
Cook for 2 hours and 30 minutes, then turn off, cool and chill in the stock.
The next day, lift out the chilled hocks and rinse off the jellied stock.
Pull out the second smaller bone, then trim off the rind and discard.
Lightly score the meat that's left and place into a non-stick baking tray.
Preheat the oven to 200C/Gas 6.
Combine the sugar, cider, tamarind, cloves, mustard, oil, honey and paprika together, mix well.
Pour over the hocks and place into the hot oven. Cook for 20-25 minutes, spooning the glaze over repeatedly until well glazed.
Serve in deep bowls, and just pull off the meat in large chunks.
You can eat this hot or cold, with buttery mashed potatoes and some glazed red cabbage.

ingredients.text: 400 g strong white flour plus extra for dusting
150 g salted butter, at room temperature, plus extra for brushing

instructions.text: Brush a 15cm diameter cake tin or souffle dish with a little butter then line with a double layer of greaseproof paper, ensuring you leave "collar" of paper 8cm above the top of the tin. Oil the inside of a large bowl.
Melt the yeast in the milk, making sure that is is completely dissolved.

Setting aside 2 tablespoons of flour, sift the remaining amount into a large bowl, sprinkle over the salt and make a well in the centre. Pour in the yeast and milk with the whole eggs and gently mix all the ingredients together to make a thick batter. Sprinkle over the reserved flour and leave the sponge in a a warm place for 35 minutes.

Add in the sugar and egg yolks and mix together to create a soft dough. Work in the soft butter and then turn out onto a lightly-floured surface. Knead for five minutes until smooth and elastic and shape into a ball.
Place the dough ball in the oiled bowl and cover with clingfilm. Leave it to rise in a warm place away from draughts for 2 hours.

Turn out the dough onto a lightly-floured surface and punch down. Gently knead in the cnadied peel and raisins. Shape again into a ball and place in the prepared tin. Cover with clingfilm and and leave to rise in a warm place away from draughts for one hour.
Preheat the oven to 190C/ gas mark 5.
Use a sharp knife to cut a cross on the top and brush with a little butter.
Bake in the middle of the oven for 20 minutes. Lower the temperature to 180C/ gas mark 4, brush the top with more butter and continue to cook for a further 30 minutes.
Once out of the oven, cool the cake in the tin for 10 minutes then turn out onto a wire rack to cool.
Panettone is perfect served at room temperature with a cup of tea.
Lay out the poppadoms.
Spoon in a little hummus, keeping away from the edge.
Top with a coriander sprig, then the prawn.
Just before serving add a pinch of paprika. Serve straight away.

recipes.title: Baked Alaska with cranberries and brandy

ingredients.text: 100 g dried cranberries (can use frozen, but be sure to thaw and drain thoroughly)

instructions.text: First soak the cranberries and dried fruit in a little brandy, preferably over night or at least for a couple of hours. Drain before using.
Preheat the oven to 190 degrees Celsius/ gas mark 5.
Soften the ice cream in a bowl using a wooden spoon. Mix in the brandy soaked dried fruits and cranberries.
Using a loaf tin (rectangular in shape) line with cling film then put the mixed ice cream inside and place into the freezer to reset.
Using a mixer, make the sponge. Cream the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy then add the eggs a little at a time. Once mixed fold in the flour.

Pour the mix out onto a baking tray lined with greaseproof paper and place into the oven for around 10-15 minutes until lightly golden and set. You can tell when it is cooked by inserting a skewer into the centre, if it comes out clean, then the sponge is cooked. Remove and allow to cool.
Make the meringue by beating the egg whites in an electric mixer adding the sugar a little at a time until you have stiff peaks.
Cut the sponge into approximately the same shape as the ice cream and brush with raspberry jam.
Lay one piece of sponge on a tray with the raspberry jam facing up, and then turn out the ice cream and place on top, then another layer of sponge jam side down.

Spread over the meringue covering completely. You can use a piping bag trying to create a few peaks in the meringue or simply spread it with a flat knife or spatula. Place back into the freezer until solid. This should take a couple of hours so this dish is perfect to do the night before.
Preheat the oven to 200 degrees Celsius/ gas mark 6.
Once solid, remove and bake in the oven for 8-10 minutes, until the meringue is coloured.
Heat up the brandy, pour over the top and light just before serving. Merry Christmas!

ingredients.text: 1 sheet of shop bought puff pastry
8 marinated cherries, chopped finely (you can buy these, or soak fresh ones in a little brandy overnight)
1 medium sized piece of crystallised stem ginger, chopped finely

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4.
Roll out the puff pastry to .5-cm thick and 18-¬îcm in length, dusting with icing sugar whilst rolling. Allow to rest for 10-15 minutes then egg wash half of the puff pastry.
Mix the mincemeat with the marinated cherries, almonds and brandy.

Using a spoon, place a large tablespoon of the mincemeat mix evenly apart on top of the egg washed puff pastry. Then fold over the other half of the puff pastry on top of the mincemeat so it is sandwiched in-between the pastry.
Gently press the pastry around the edges of the mincemeat to get rid of any trapped air.
Take a 2.5-cm diameter plain pastry cutter and cut out the mince pies, brush the tops with egg wash and sprinkle with granulated sugar.
Place onto a non stick baking tray and cook for around 10-15 minutes or until risen and golden brown.
Meanwhile, make the serving cream. Mix all of the ingredients together and refrigerate until needed. (This cream also goes brilliantly with Christmas pudding).
Remove the mince pies from the oven, dust with icing sugar and serve with a dollop of the cream.

ingredients.text: 6 thick cut slices of country rustic bread (with a dense texture is best)
2 large, ripe plum tomatoes, cut in half
Salt and freshly ground black pepper

instructions.text: Preheat the grill.

Toast the bread doorsteps on both sides. Remove from the grill and whilst hot, rub one side with the garlic cloves. Rub the garlic side of the bread with the cut side of the tomatoes. Arrange the garlic hunks on a wooden board , drizzle over the extra virgin olive oil and season with a little salt and freshly ground black pepper.

recipes.title: Red wine poached pears with shortbread

ingredients.text: 1 quantity of mulled wine, see recipe below
4 firm-ish but ripe dessert pears (very ripe will not work for this recipe)
1 orange, peel only (use a potato peeler to remove the peel)
Clotted cream ice cream, to serve

instructions.text: For the mulled wine, add one large glass full of red wine to a saucepan with the other ingredients. Boil rapidly until the wine has reduced by half. This is an important step in order to infuse the wine with all the flavours.
Add the rest of the wine, turn the heat off and leave for an hour or so to fully infuse.
Peel the pears and pop them in a bowl of water with a squeeze of lemon juice, this will stop them going brown. When you are ready to use them cut the bottoms off so they stand up easily.
Put the pears in a deep saucepan and cover with the mulled wine.
You can roll the pears on their sides which will make them easier to cover.
Turn the heat onto medium and when it‚Äôs simmering poach the pears for around 30 minutes or until a knife easily pierces the flesh.
You don‚Äôt want them too soft they should still have a little bite to them.

For the shortbread, mix together the butter sugar and flour in a food processor until a smooth dough is formed. Don‚Äôt over work the mix or the shortbread won‚Äôt be short. Just mix it until it comes together.
Roll or pat out and pop on a lightly greased baking sheet.
Bake on 160C/gas 2 for 25 minutes.

When the shortbread comes out of the oven it will be soft, don‚Äôt worry it hardens on cooling. When it's soft is the time to cut it into your desired shapes or do the traditional fork prick marks all over.
Sprinkle with caster sugar and serve with the pears.
A little of the syrup drizzled over the pears always goes down a treat.

ingredients.text: 100 g mixed peel (preferably chopped yourself) of orange, lemon and citron
25 g whole almonds, blanched and chopped
500 g packet of white bread mix
50 g glace cherries, cut into quarters

instructions.text: Soak the apricots, sultanas, raisins and mixed peel in rum overnight.
Mix in the nuts and lemon rind.
Put the butter, sugar and bread mix into a food processor bowl fitted with a dough attachment. Mix for 1 or 2 minutes until the butter is incorporated.
Blend the almond and vanilla essence with the warm water and add, together with the beaten egg, to the bowl. Mix for 5 minutes to form a dough and then rest the dough for 5 minutes.
Add the dried fruit soaked in rum, nuts and lemon rind and mix into the dough.
Remove the dough from the bowl on to a floured surface. Knead until smooth then divide it and reshape it into two rounds. Rest the dough for 5 minutes.
Divide the marzipan into two pieces and roll each into a sausage shape.
Pat out each piece of dough with the heel of your hand to form a 20-cm round. Place the marzipan slightly off-centre on the dough. Sprinkle each half with the cherries.
Brush over the surface of the dough with water to moisten, then fold the smaller side over the marzipan to cover it and leave a ledge of dough.
Cover the dough with a clean tea towel or lightly oiled plastic film and leave in a warm place for 40-45 minutes or until doubled in size.
Bake in a preheated oven at 200C/Gas 6/fan oven 180C for 25-30 minutes or until golden brown. To test if it is cooked, give the base a sharp tap - it should sound hollow when it is done.

Remove the bread from the oven and drench it with melted butter, making sure it soaks in between each application - this helps to keep the dough fresh for longer. Cool the stollen on a wire rack. Dust heavily with icing sugar.

Freezing: The stollen can be frozen for up to 1 month. Do not dust with icing sugar before freezing; wrap in greaseproof paper and foil and then freeze. To thaw, keep at room temperature overnight and then dust with icing sugar.
Tip: To prepare as a gift, tie a ribbon around the stollen like a parcel and wrap it in cellophane.

ingredients.text: 2 -3 tbsp finely chopped flat leaf parsley
Sea salt and freshly ground white pepper

instructions.text: Peel the celeriac and cut in half. Slice thinly (3mm julienne), or slice on a mandolin slicer with a julienne blade attached (but watch your fingers!).

Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to the boil and drop in all of your sliced celeriac. Cook for no more than 1 minutes, then drain and put into a bowl of cold water to refresh. Drain, then refill with water and drain again. This is to ensure that the celeriac has stopped cooking and is all cooled. When cooled, pat dry with paper towels to soak up as much water as possible.
Put the celeriac in a bowl and toss with the lemon juice. Let stand uncovered in the fridge for about 2 hours.
Pour the celeriac into a fine strainer and place over the empty bowl to let excess lemon juice drip off. Let stand for about 1 hour uncovered.
Peel the apple and julienne to the same size as the celeriac.
Combine the mayonnaise with the dry mustard and add as much as 1 tablespoon of lemon juice to thin it out a bit, and mix well. Season to taste with salt and white pepper.
Toss the dressing with the celeriac, apple, chives, capers and parsley. Mix well and chill for about 2 hours.
Serve in butter lettuce cups and garnish with halved cherry tomatoes.

recipes.title: Roast pork belly with maple crackling and spiced pears

ingredients.text: 1½ kg whole pork belly, rib bones removed
4 tbsp maple syrup, for the crackling
4 King Edward potatoes, peeled and cubed
4 ripe firm Comice pears, peeled, cored and cut into quarters

instructions.text: Preheat oven to a high heat, 220C/Gas 7.

Prepare the pork belly. Using a sharp knife score lines around 1cm apart across the skin of the belly, deep enough to cut through the skin but do not cut the meat. (A good tip is to use a clean Stanley knife for this but please be very careful and make sure it is spotlessly clean before and after using). Rub fine salt all over the pork along with the lemon zest. Place the rough cut vegetables, garlic, bay and half of the thyme into a deep baking tray. Lay the pork on top and put in a hot oven for 25 minutes or until the skin is starting to look crisp, then lower the heat to 180C/Gas 4 and cook for a further two hours. Remember to wash your hands thoroughly after handling raw meat.

Whilst the pork is cooking prepare the mash. For the mash, simply boil the potatoes and celeriac in water until soft, then drain and mash with a knob of butter, seasoning and a splash of milk. Set aside and warm up when required.

Check the pork, after the two hours the crackling should be crisp and the meat tender. Carefully remove from the tray and put onto another baking tray. Heat the maple syrup with the remaining thyme, then brush all over the crackling. Leave the meat to rest loosely covered with a piece of tin foil. Do not wrap up tightly as the crackling will go soft!

Next, take the baking tray with the cooked vegetable in and skim off any fat from the meat juices. Put the tray on a high heat on the hob, add the cider and crumble in the stock cube. Add the star anise and simmer. Reduce by half, stirring occasionally.

Take the pears and saut√© in a non stick pan with the 5 spice for two minutes, then using a sieve pour the cider juices over the pears. Using a ladle and the sieve, squeeze the vegetables out over the pear pan. Simmer the cider and pears gently to a thin sauce consistency until the pears are softened.
To serve, cut a slice of pork belly, add a spoonful of hot mash and spoon on some pear pieces. Finally drizzle over the sauce and serve.

ingredients.text: 1 large chicken breast, cut into bite-sized pieces
¾ tsp smoked paprika, adjust to your taste
1 chicken stock cube, melted in 3/4 pint of boiling water
Slices of crusty bread, to serve

instructions.text: Spray a large pan with oil and fry the chopped onions until soft. Add the chicken pieces and continue cooking for 5 minutes.

Add the chorizo, peppers, garlic and paprika and stir for a further 5 minutes. Add the tinned tomatoes and stock and stir together along with the sugar, salt and pepper. Once everything is combined, check for seasoning and strength of paprika. Add a little more paprika, sugar or salt and pepper if needed.
Cook for about 15 minutes on a low heat until all flavours are infused. Take out 2 ladles and liquidise along with the cr√®me fraiche. Tip back into the soup and mix well.
Serve piping hot with an extra blob of cr√®me fraiche if desired and a slice of crusty bread.

ingredients.text: Giblets (liver, gizzard and heart) and neck from one turkey
3 medium thick slices of smoked streaky bacon, fried to lightly crisp
16 slices of half dried whole or cracked wheat bread cubes, cut into 1.5-cm cubes
1 tbsp poultry seasoning (dried thyme, sage, marjoram, rosemary, nutmeg and black pepper)
1½ tsp fresh thyme, or 1/2 tsp dried thyme
Freshly ground black pepper, to taste

instructions.text: The night or several hours before cooking, braise the turkey neck in water with the onion ends, celery tops and parsley stems in a covered saucepan over very low heat for about two hours.
Cool the neck bones, remove all the meat from them and return the bones to the braising water for another half hour and simmer.
Strain the braising water into a bowl (should equal about 480ml) and add the butter and 1 tablespoon of dry sherry.

Cook the giblets in a little vegetable oil then trim the gizzard. Next, either finely chop or coarsely process in a food processor the neck meat, giblets, bacon and garlic clove. The texture should be that of beef mince.

In a large bowl, mix the bread cubes with the celery and onions. Sprinkle the poultry seasoning over the mixture, then add the ground/chopped meat mixture, mushrooms, parsley, thyme and sage. Mix well.

Sprinkle the the mixture with the reserved stock mixture, a little at a time until the bread cubes are uniformly moist. Adjust seasoning to taste. The mixture should not be heavy and soggy so adjust the amount of stock depending on how dry your bread cubes are. The vegetables will release moisture during the baking process and you don't want it too be too runny when cooked. If it is too wet when removed from the turkey you can bake it separately for about 15 minutes uncovered at 150C/Gas 2 to firm it up a bit.

If you choose not to stuff the turkey, you can cook this separately in a large rectangular baking dish. Cover with aluminium foil and bake at 160C/Gas 2 for 30 minutes and then uncover and bake for 15 minutes more to crisp the top.
Heat the beef bouillon in a small pan or in the microwave.
Stir in the seasonings and heat through.
Remove from the heat and stir in the measure of vodka. Drink up!

recipes.title: Beef fillet with baby spinach and fondant potatoes

ingredients.text: 4 white potatoes, peeled and cut into barrel-shapes
1 heaped tbsp full fat cr√®me fraiche

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 4.

Heat the butter in a pan, add the potatoes and fry until nicely coloured all over. Then put them in an ovenproof dish with the chicken stock, thyme and a bay leaf and place them in the bottom of the oven for roughly an hour ‚Äì making sure that you keep basting them. Season, to taste with salt and freshly ground black pepper.

Soften some shallots with butter, chuck in a bit of garlic, some chicken stock and reduce down with a bay leaf and some thyme. Add some red wine, salt, pepper and reduce down to a sauce like consistency.

Wash the spinach thoroughly and then drain it. Take a pan and heat through. Melt the butter and when it‚Äôs hot, not smoking, put in all of the spinach a couple of handfuls at a time. When the spinach has all wilted, drain and press away the excess water with a wooden spoon. Then mix in the cr√®me fra√Æche, garlic, salt, pepper and freshly grated horseradish and heat through.
Sear the beef in the pan with the duck fat and a knob of butter until cooked to your liking.
Serve the beef on the plate with some of the creamed spinach and a fondant potato and sauce drizzled over and around.

ingredients.text: 1 small tin of reduced sugar baked beans (about 200g)

instructions.text: Dry fry the onions, peppers and curry powder in a hot pan and add the beans and warm through. Serve with grilled veggie sausages.
You could also serve these with mashed potatoes, but watch how much butter you add to them to keep the fat content low. Alternatively, serve with some mashed sweet potatoes.

ingredients.text: Salad leaves and a couple cherry tomatoes, to serve

instructions.text: Put the cr√®me fraiche, horseradish and gherkin in a small bowl and mix. Then add the beetroot and potato and stir. Serve with the smoked mackerel and salad leaves. Simple!

ingredients.text: 1x 300 g pot of light cottage cheese
4 rye crisp breads or 2 small slices of toast
1x 125 ml small glass of fresh vegetable juice, to serve

instructions.text: Stir the pineapple into the cheese and top the rye crisp breads with the fruity cheese! Serve with the carrots, cucumber and apple on the side with a glass of vegetable juice.

recipes.title: Sticky honey, pomegranate and Ottoman-spiced chicken wings

instructions.text: In a large, uncovered saucepan, on a medium heat, stir all the ingredients until the sugar has completely dissolved. Reduce the heat to a simmer and cook for roughly an hour, or until the juice has a syrupy consistency and has reduced to about a quarter. Pour into a jar, allow to cool, then store in the refrigerator for up to 4weeks. Alternatively, once cooled pour over the chicken to marinate.

Combine the pomegranate molasses, pomegranate juice, honey and garlic in a bowl. Add the chicken wings and thoroughly coat with the pomegranate marinade. Cover and refrigerate for at least 4hours or overnight.
Meanwhile, mix all the bararat spices together.
Preheat the oven to 180C/Gas 6.

Arrange the marinated chicken wings on a large baking tray and sprinkle liberally with the Ottoman spice blend, putting aside a little for later. Roast for 30-40 minutes, until golden. Sprinkle on the remaining spice and pomegranate seeds just before serving.

ingredients.text: 800 g stewing steak, cut into 3cm cubes
120 g streaky bacon, cut into strips
400 g tomatoes, skinned, de-seeded and chopped

instructions.text: Put the flour into a large bowl and season well with salt and pepper. Toss in the cubes of beef so they become coated with the flour.

Put a drizzle of olive oil in a large frying pan and place over a high heat. Add the meat and brown it on all sides ¬ñ- do this in batches so as not to overcrowd the pan -¬ñ then transfer it to a large casserole when it is done. Now reduce the heat, add a little more oil to the frying pan if necessary and fry the onions until lightly browned. Add them to the beef with the garlic. Finally cook the bacon until browned, adding that to the beef too.

Mix the beef in the casserole with the paprika and mixed spice, place over the heat and cook for 1 minute. Add the red wine, chopped tomatoes and stock, give everything a good stir and bring to the boil. Season with salt and pepper, cover and transfer to an oven preheated to 180¬∞C/Gas Mark 4. Cook for 45 minutes, then reduce the temperature to 150¬∞C/Gas Mark 2 and cook for another 1¬º hours, until the meat is tender. Check after about an hour that the casserole hasn'¬ít become too dry, and add a little more stock or water if necessary.

In the meantime put the peppers under a hot grill or directly on a gas burner and leave until blackened and blistered all over, turning occasionally. Cool slightly, then skin and de-seed the peppers and cut the flesh into strips.
When the beef is done, stir in the red peppers and adjust the seasoning. Serve garnished with the parsley, accompanied by the soured cream and some basmati rice.

recipes.title: Roast duck breasts with kale and chestnuts

ingredients.text: 4 medium sized duck breasts, with the sinew removed from the under carriage and seasoned

750 ml (use 600ml for the celeriac and swede and 150ml for the sauce) brown chicken stock (this just means to use dark chicken stock rather than the light pre made chicken stock you can buy ‚Äì stock cubes are fine)
100 g smoked bacon, cut into lardons
8 cooked chestnuts, diced (use the vacuum packed variety, they are usually the best quality)
2 handfuls of curly kale, blanched (this simply means to plunge into boiling salted water for 2-3 minutes then remove)

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 180/ gas mark 4.

In a preheated thick-bottom oven proof frying pan, add a good drizzle of vegetable oil and once hot, add the seasoned duck breasts, fat side down. Colour on all sides until golden brown then place skin side down in the same pan and into a preheated oven for 8 minutes. Remove and allow to rest in a warm place. Keep the pan to one side for later.

Meanwhile, place the swede into a pan, season, add a knob of butter, thyme and the bay leaves then cover with chicken stock (use approximately 300ml). Cook the swede over a medium heat for around 5-6 minutes, then add the celeriac and another 300ml chicken stock to cover and cook for another 5-6 minutes or until both vegetables are tender. Drain and mash separately, then mix together adding a good drizzle of extra-virgin olive oil and seasoning.

In a separate pan, add the bacon lardons and cook until golden, then add the chestnuts and cook for a further minute. Add the blanched curly kale and cook for 2 minutes, then pour in the cream and cook for a further 2 minutes.

Taking the pan that the duck was cooked in, tip away the excess fat and place back onto a high heat, add the shallot and colour for a few minutes. Pour in the balsamic vinegar and reduce by half, then add 150ml of brown chicken stock and reduce until a sauce consistency is achieved. Finish with butter.

To serve, place the chestnut curly kale on one side of the plate, slice the duck and place on top, then using large serving spoons, place a good mound of swede and celeriac puree on the other side of the plate and drizzle over the sauce.

recipes.title: Steak with red wine, mushroom and thyme sauce

ingredients.text: Sea salt and freshly ground black pepper
450 g potatoes, washed and cut into very thin chips

instructions.text: To cook the steaks, heat a large nonstick frying pan until hot. Rub the rump steaks all over with the olive oil and season well with freshly ground black pepper and sea salt.

Place the steaks in the hot pan (no more than 2 at a time) and cook for approx 5-6 minutes in total, turning after each minute for medium rare or 1-2 minutes longer, depending on thickness, or if you prefer your meat well done.
Lift the steaks out of the pan and place on a plate.
To make the sauce in the steak pan, melt the butter, add the shallots and mushrooms and fry over a medium heat for 5 minutes. Stir in the flour and toast, stirring for 1 minute.
Turn up the heat and pour the wine into the pan. Add the thyme, stock and port. Boil rapidly over a high heat until the sauce has reduced by half.
Remove from the heat and whisk the butter into the sauce to give a glossy finish. Serve with the steak and skinny chips.
Place the chips in a large bowl and drizzle with the olive oil and season well.
Spread the chips on a roasting tray lined with baking parchment and place in a preheated 200C/Gas 6 oven for 20-25 minutes, turning occasionally until golden and crisp.
Dice and cube the pork.
Place the pork in a bowl, then add Thai red curry paste, curry powder, brown sugar, fish sauce, thick soy sauce, 1 chopped pickled garlic bulb and 1 tablespoon of pickled garlic sauce.
Massage the marinade into the pork until it is coated and covered. Leave at room temperature for one hour.

Whilst the pork is marinating, make the Thai salad; mix the white vinegar and white sugar and boil and cool. Then chop the carrot, cucumber, peppers, chillies, red onions and mix in the vinegar and leave to one side.

Fry the marinated pork in vegetable oil, add 750ml of water, bring to boil and simmer for an hour. Whilst simmering, add 2 sliced white onions, half a garlic bulb, 3 tablespoons of tamarind juice, pineapple and sliced ginger towards the end.
Boil the rice until cooked.
Just before serving, fry the bean sprouts add one clove of chopped garlic and one and a half tablespoons of light soy sauce, then add sliced spring onions.
Put the steaming hot jasmine rice in the centre of a plate with curry around it, Thai salad sprinkled on top with a side plate if having the fried bean sprouts.

ingredients.text: Half a glass of white wine

instructions.text: Chop the vegetables and put them in a low pot with some olive oil and fry until they soften.

Add the meat and wine and cook slowly for about five minutes. After that, adjust with salt and keep cooking for about 20 minutes, until the liquids (from the vegetables, the meat and the wine ) is dry.
When the meat is ready pass it into the mixer to have a kind of p√¢t√©. Add one egg, the cheese and season with pepper and ground nutmeg as you like.

Divide the pasta in to four pieces and start to roll it with the pasta machine. Pass each piece in the pasta machine at least five times, from the bigger thickness to the one you desire. (I normally arrive to the one before the thickest).
Lay a pasta sheet on a clean surface (put some flour on before) and start to distribute small quantities of filling (about a small cherry) with intervals of five centimetres.
Bend the pasta over the filling and take out the air around the filling making pressure with your fingers.
Cut with a rounded cutter and make an half moon.
Take the half moon with your hands and attach the two corners together keeping the ‚Äúbelly‚Äù of the cappelleto risen. Put the cappelletti in a tray with some semolina.
Cook them in the boiling broth for at least two to three minutes.
The cappelletti will be served in a bowl with the beef stock in which they have been cooked with some grated parmesan on top.

ingredients.text: 100 g sun dried tomatoes (dried, not in oil)
5 ml red wine, Chianti or Montepulciano
Sea salt and black pepper to season
1 large white Spanish onion or 3 echalion shallots
Sea salt and black pepper to season
80 g mixed herb salad (lambs lettuce,rocket, gourmet medley of lollo rossi, lollo
Biondi and red oak leaf salad
200 g cherry tomatoes on the vine
Sea salt and black pepper to season

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 180C.
Wash all Roma tomatoes and cut into quarters.
Place tomatoes evenly on two roasting tins, drizzle with some olive oil and season with sea salt and black pepper.
Roast the tomatoes in oven.

Make the pasta; put the tipo 00 flour in a large bowl or on a counter top. Make a well in the middle of the flour and put the eight egg yolks in the middle. Beat the yolks and mix in the flour slowly until it forms into a dough ball.
Remove the tomatoes from the oven allow to cool.
Place semolina flour on a counter top, add chopped basil and knead the pasta dough until it becomes soft and silky.
Wrap in cling film and place in the fridge.
Boil eggs in a small saucepan.
Place a large mixing bowl until the food mill. Sieve tomatoes through the food mill into the mixing bowl. Sieve through twice and discard all of the tomato skins.
Pour the sieved tomatoes into a large saucepan and add salt, pepper, wine and oregano and simmer.
Taste the sauce and add seasoning if needed. Add sundried tomatoes to passata sauce, put lid on top then simmer on a low heat.
Chop the onion and garlic, saut√© in a large pan along with the minced beef. Season with salt and pepper and stir every few minutes until it is cooked through to a golden brown.
Take the pasta out of the fridge, dust work surface with tipo 00 flour or semolina flour and break into three balls.
Flatten each ball of pasta dough and run through pasta machine starting from the widest setting down to the lowest setting. Each time turning the pasta round and re-flouring as necessary.
Continue this with all the pasta until it is as thin as a playing card. Then hang it on a pasta stand to dry out for a few moments.
Drain excess oil from minced beef.
Grease the lasagne tray with some olive oil. Cover the bottom with passata sauce.
Cut out two sheets of lasagna pasta. Cover with more sauce.
Add a third of the minced beef, petite pois, half a chopped egg, mozzarella, parmesan and fresh basil.
Cut out two more lasagne pasta sheets and place on top.
Repeat the above three times. Add passata sauce to top and place in the centre of the oven for about 25 minutes.
Melt butter in a saucepan on a low heat, add flour and mix continuously making a roux.
Slowly add sieved plain flour, continuously stirring to get a rich creamy mixture. Add nutmeg and take off the heat.

Add the b√©chamel sauce to the top of the pasta and cook for a further 15 minutes. Put the vine tomatoes and artichoke hearts into an oven safe dish and drizzle with olive oil and grill for 15 minutes.
Take the pasta out of the oven and let sit for five minutes.
Preheat plates in oven.
Wash salad and toss it together with lemon juice.

ingredients.text: 400 g fresh raspberries, loganberries or tayberries

instructions.text: Prepare a Swiss roll tin with baking parchment and preheat the oven to 180C/gas 4.
Melt the butter in a small pan and set aside to cool.

Sift the flour and salt into a small bowl. Put the eggs and sugar in a heatproof bowl that will sit snugly inside a saucepan, then half-fill the saucepan with boiling water and sit the bowl on top. Whisk the eggs and sugar with an electric hand whisk until pale and thick.
Sift in the seasoned flour and fold into the egg mixture, then fold in the melted butter.
Turn into the prepared cake tin and bake in the oven for 25 minutes until golden brown and springy to touch.
Remove the sponges from the oven and leave aside to cool completely.

Whilst the sponges are cooking, make the custard. Pour the milk into a saucepan. Cut the vanilla pod down the centre with a sharp knife and add to the pan. Bring the milk slowly to the boil. Once it reaches almost boiling point, remove from the heat and allow to stand so the vanilla can infuse into the milk.
Whisk the egg yolks together with the sugar until thick and pale in colour then add the milk and stir.
Pour the custard into a clean pan and place over a low heat, stirring constantly until it thickens. Remove from the heat, pour into a jug and refrigerate until needed.
Very lightly whip the cream and combine with the mascarpone. Set aside in the fridge until needed.
Wash the raspberries and oranges.
Using an orange zester, pare the zest from the oranges and put into a bowl, reserving a few strands for decoration later.
Squeeze the oranges and add the juice to a bowl. Mix in the Glayva liqueur and leave aside.

Once cool, cut the sponges into small blocks and soak them in the liqueur mix. Use to layer four individual trifle bowls. Spoon over a good layer of raspberries then top with the custard. Finish off by piping the whipped cream mixture over the top.
Lay out a good handful of slivered almonds and medium oatmeal on some foil and toast lightly under the grill until golden. Cool for a few minutes then sprinkle over the top of each trifle.
Serve the Tipsy laird in the centre of the plate and finish with a drizzle of runny honey and some of the reserved orange zest.
